	<wp:category><wp:term_id>7</wp:term_id><wp:category_nicename>eau</wp:category_nicename><wp:category_parent></wp:category_parent><wp:cat_name><![CDATA[Eau et Assainissement]]></wp:cat_name><wp:category_description><![CDATA[En RDC comme partout dans le monde, l’UNICEF s’emploie à améliorer l’approvisionnement en eau et les installations sanitaires des écoles et des collectivités et à promouvoir des pratiques hygiéniques. Nous apportons notre soutien à de multiples et diverses activités et coopérons avec de nombreux partenaires, dont des familles, des collectivités, des gouvernements et des organisations porteuses des mêmes valeurs. 

En situation d'urgence, nous apportons des secours d’urgence aux collectivités et nations risquant de ne plus être approvisionnées en eau et menacées par des maladies. Tous les programmes de l’UNICEF en matière d’eau et d’assainissement sont conçus pour contribuer à la réalisation de l’Objectif du Millénaire pour le développement lié à l’eau et à l’assainissement : réduire de moitié, d’ici à 2015, la proportion de personnes n’ayant pas durablement accès à l’eau salubre et à des installations sanitaires de base.]]></wp:category_description></wp:category>

	<wp:category><wp:term_id>118</wp:term_id><wp:category_nicename>rrmp</wp:category_nicename><wp:category_parent></wp:category_parent><wp:cat_name><![CDATA[RRMP]]></wp:cat_name></wp:category>
	<wp:category><wp:term_id>117</wp:term_id><wp:category_nicename>sante</wp:category_nicename><wp:category_parent></wp:category_parent><wp:cat_name><![CDATA[Santé]]></wp:cat_name></wp:category>
	<wp:category><wp:term_id>144</wp:term_id><wp:category_nicename>savoir-pour-sauver</wp:category_nicename><wp:category_parent></wp:category_parent><wp:cat_name><![CDATA[Savoir pour sauver]]></wp:cat_name><wp:category_description><![CDATA[Savoir pour Sauver a pour but de donner aux familles et aux communautés les informations dont elles ont besoin pour protéger les enfants et améliorer leur existence. 

Les parents, les grands parents, les personnes qui s’occupent d’enfants et les jeunes peuvent consulter cette source d’informations pratiques pour y trouver les réponses à leurs questions et apprendre comment donner aux enfants le meilleur départ dans la vie. 

Les messages regroupés dans Savoir pour Sauver se fondent sur les découvertes scientifiques les plus récentes et sur les droits de l’homme, en particulier la Convention relative aux droits de l’enfant et la Convention pour l’élimination de toutes les formes de discrimination à l’égard des femmes.

Tout le monde peut faire passer les messages de Savoir pour Sauver!]]></wp:category_description></wp:category>

	<wp:category><wp:term_id>14</wp:term_id><wp:category_nicename>urgences</wp:category_nicename><wp:category_parent></wp:category_parent><wp:cat_name><![CDATA[Urgences]]></wp:cat_name><wp:category_description><![CDATA[Each subject begins with the opportunity to show a block of text that describes the subject and gives an overview and context to the individual posts to follow.

	<wp:category><wp:term_id>119</wp:term_id><wp:category_nicename>villages-assainis</wp:category_nicename><wp:category_parent></wp:category_parent><wp:cat_name><![CDATA[Villages Assainis]]></wp:cat_name><wp:category_description><![CDATA[Un village assaini, qu’est-ce que c’est?
1. Un village ayant un comité dynamique
2. Au moins 80 % de la population a accès à l’eau potable
3. Au moins 80 % des ménages utilisent une latrine hygiénique
4. Au moins 80 % des parcelles sont propres
5. Au moins 60 % de la population se lave les mains avec du savon ou de la cendre avant de manger et après avoir été aux toilettes
6. Au moins 70 % de la population comprend le schéma de transmission des maladies à partir des matières fécales et es mesures de prévention
7. Le village est nettoyé au moins une fois par mois

Et une école assainie ?
1. 100 % du personnel enseignant formé à la stratégie « École Assainie », en Education à la Santé et à l’Environnement, et 100 % du COPA sensibilisé
2. 80 % de manuels pour élèves disponibles : 1 manuel pour 2 élèves ou 1 guide par enseignant
3. 1 porte pour 40 filles et 1 porte pour 50 garçons et 80 % de latrines hygiéniques
4. 100 % d’eau potable disponible et 80 % d’élèves se lavant les mains avec du savon ou de la cendre
5. 1 fois par jour, cour d’école et salles de classe sont balayées/nettoyées et déchets jetés dans un trou à ordure
6. 100 % des brigadiers de santé et d’environnement élus dans les écoles sensibilisés et Opérationnels

L’approche “Village assaini” pas à pas
0.	La communauté prend connaissance du programme et décide collectivement d’y adhérer, puis soumet une demande formelle a la zone de sante.
1.	Signature du protocole d’accord entre la communauté et la zone de sante.
2.	La communauté élit un comité de village après que la zone de sante ait forme une ving-taine de volontaires sur ce point.
3.	Les acteurs de la zone de sante réalisent une enquête sur les comportements, attitudes et pratiques des ménages du village.
4.	La communauté analyse ses conditions d’hygiène et d’assainissement, grâce à la carto-graphie communautaire, la promenade d’observation, le classement de dessins des conditions d’hygiène en 3 catégories et l’analyse des voies de transmission féco-orales.
5.	La communauté élabore son Plan d’action communautaire, en classant les interventions décidées par priorités.
6.	La communauté met en oeuvre les activités nécessaires pour améliorer son accès à l’eau et l’assainissement. Les volontaires font la promotion des bonnes pratiques d’hygiène.
7.	L’enquête finale : le bureau de la zone de santé réalise une étude des nouvelles connais-sances, attitudes et pratiques acquises par la communauté.
8.	Le médecin-chef de zone vérifie si le village a atteint les normes exigées pour être déclaré Village Assaini. Si c’est le cas, le médecin accorde son certificat au village au cours d’une célébration. 

]]></wp:category_description></wp:category>
	<wp:category><wp:term_id>15</wp:term_id><wp:category_nicename>blog</wp:category_nicename><wp:category_parent></wp:category_parent><wp:cat_name><![CDATA[Vos Questions]]></wp:cat_name><wp:category_description><![CDATA[Mattis etiam in phasellus ut diam quis proin cum proin hac sit, arcu porttitor, tincidunt ultrices turpis sed arcu, integer augue elit in risus, sed, adipiscing elementum nunc proin amet, placerat etiam aliquam! 	<item>
		<title>NYHQ2005-2204</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/?attachment_id=1435</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 May 2013 15:50:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>stevebutton</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/UNI44479.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Children smile, at a nonformal education centre in Kinsenso, a poor settlement on the outskirts of Kinshasha, the capital. The UNICEF-supported centre provides basic education to children who have left traditional schools for a variety of reasons. Part of the UNICEF logo is visible on the banner behind them.

In 2005 in the Democratic Republic of Congo, the situation for children remains precarious. The nation is among the least developed in the world, with 80 per cent of its population living below the poverty line and some 40,000 children living on the street. Instability continues to hamper relief efforts in the north-eastern region, where a seven-year civil war has killed 4 million Congolese, many from starvation and disease. UNICEF continues to work with other relief groups to meet the basic needs of children and women displaced by the conflict, as well as to support child soldier demobilization efforts. An improved security situation in some areas has permitted greater access to children in conflict zones, while allowing some resources to be redirected toward health, education and protection in other parts of the country. Assistance has also been scaled up for children living or working on the streets, orphans and child labourers. UNICEF supports early childhood development and primary education, especially for girls and children whose education has been disrupted by conflict; immunization, nutrition and growth-monitoring programmes; HIV/AIDS awareness and prevention training; and ongoing provision of emergency health, water and sanitation services.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1435</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-05-16 15:50:14</wp:post_date>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>nyhq2005-2204</wp:post_name>

		<title>sophie_blackall_1</title>

	<item>
		<title>NYHQ2005-0439</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/?attachment_id=1445</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 May 2013 15:50:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>stevebutton</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/UNI41652.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Boys raise their hands to shield their faces and their identities as former child soldiers, at a UNICEF-supported Centre de Transit et Orientation (CTO), a shelter and reintegration centre for recently demobilized child soldiers, in the eastern town of Goma, capital of North Kivu Province. The CTO provides medical and psychosocial care, as well as family tracing and reunification services. Nationwide, over 33,000 child soldiers remain active.

In March 2005 in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), insecurity and massive population displacements continue to challenge relief efforts in the eastern part of the country. An upsurge in violence in the resource-rich Ituri region, including the killing in February of nine MONUC (United Nations Organization Mission in the DRC) peacekeepers, led to a temporary suspension in humanitarian aid to tens of thousands of displaced civilians. Over two-thirds of the displaced are children and women. As aid resumes, the number of displaced continues to grow: up to 88,000 are registered in camps but many more are assumed to be in need of shelter. Some 6 million people throughout the north-eastern region are affected by the ongoing conflict. Hundreds of thousands are victimized in atrocities committed with impunity. Recruitment of child soldiers by all military factions continues. Rape of girls and women is a widespread weapon of war, terrorizing the population and increasing HIV prevalence. This regional fighting is part of a seven-year conflict in which up to 5 million Congolese have died from starvation, disease and warfare. UNICEF is working with other relief groups to meet the basic needs of displaced children and women, as well as to support child soldier demobilization efforts and other health, water and sanitation, education and protection initiatives in the region.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1445</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-05-16 15:50:54</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-05-16 15:50:54</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>nyhq2005-0439</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>

	<item>
		<title>NYHQ2000-0680</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/?attachment_id=1461</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 May 2013 15:51:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>stevebutton</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/UNI35076.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[On 11 August 2000, a girl stands with other children in the south-central town of Kananga, where members of the local mobile vaccination team are going from door to door during the NIDs campaign against polio to find children who have not yet been immunized against the virus.

From 10 to 13 August 2000, UNICEF Executive Director Carol Bellamy visited the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), to further global efforts to eradicate polio, especially in countries affected by conflict. One of 20 priority countries where wild poliovirus is still endemic, her visit there coincided with a National Immunization Days (NIDs) campaign targeting 11 million children. Polio eradication efforts in the country are hampered by ongoing armed conflict in six provinces affecting some 14 million Congolese, as both the national economy and health system are deteriorating. Child malnutrition in all parts of the country is rising; some 20,000 children have been recruited as child soldiers and another 20,000 have been separated from their families; 50,000 are living or working on the streets, with some forced into prostitution, including children younger than eight years old; and approximately 210,000 more are internally displaced.  During her visit, Ms. Bellamy participated in a NIDs launch, as well as in door-to-door outreach efforts to immunize the 10-20 per cent of children unable to go to the central immunization sites, and met with polio-afflicted children, government representatives and UNICEF staff. This is the second round of polio immunizations in the country in the year 2000; a third round is scheduled for September. Each child must be immunized three times to be fully protected from the polio virus.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1461</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-05-16 15:51:42</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-05-16 15:51:42</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>nyhq2000-0680</wp:post_name>

	<item>
		<title>NYHQ2000-0682</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/?attachment_id=1462</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 May 2013 15:51:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>stevebutton</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/UNI35078.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[On 11 August 2000, a girl stands smiling in the south-central town of Kananga, where members of the local mobile vaccination team are going from door to door during the NIDs campaign against polio to find children who have not yet been immunized against the virus.

From 10 to 13 August 2000, UNICEF Executive Director Carol Bellamy visited the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), to further global efforts to eradicate polio, especially in countries affected by conflict. One of 20 priority countries where wild poliovirus is still endemic, her visit there coincided with a National Immunization Days (NIDs) campaign targeting 11 million children. Polio eradication efforts in the country are hampered by ongoing armed conflict in six provinces affecting some 14 million Congolese, as both the national economy and health system are deteriorating. Child malnutrition in all parts of the country is rising; some 20,000 children have been recruited as child soldiers and another 20,000 have been separated from their families; 50,000 are living or working on the streets, with some forced into prostitution, including children younger than eight years old; and approximately 210,000 more are internally displaced.  During her visit, Ms. Bellamy participated in a NIDs launch, as well as in door-to-door outreach efforts to immunize the 10-20 per cent of children unable to go to the central immunization sites, and met with polio-afflicted children, government representatives and UNICEF staff. This is the second round of polio immunizations in the country in the year 2000; a third round is scheduled for September. Each child must be immunized three times to be fully protected from the polio virus.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>DSC_1108</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/?attachment_id=1464</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 May 2013 15:51:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>stevebutton</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/DSC_1108.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Girl smiling - the flower she wears on her forehead is for the International Women Day; at Kakoy Primary School, in Kakoy.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>NYHQ2005-2126</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/?attachment_id=1465</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 May 2013 15:51:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>stevebutton</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/UNI44401.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[A girl waits at a health centre in Kisangani, capital of the north-eastern Province Orientale. UNICEF provides the centre with essential drugs and vaccines, medical supplies, mosquito bednets for pregnant women and children under five, training for health workers, as well as bicycles and motor bikes for outreach and supervision.

In 2005 in the Democratic Republic of Congo, the situation for children remains precarious. The nation is among the least developed in the world, with 80 per cent of its population living below the poverty line and some 40,000 children living on the street. Instability continues to hamper relief efforts in the north-eastern region, where a seven-year civil war has killed 4 million Congolese, many from starvation and disease. UNICEF continues to work with other relief groups to meet the basic needs of children and women displaced by the conflict, as well as to support child soldier demobilization efforts. An improved security situation in some areas has permitted greater access to children in conflict zones, while allowing some resources to be redirected toward health, education and protection in other parts of the country. Assistance has also been scaled up for children living or working on the streets, orphans and child labourers. UNICEF supports early childhood development and primary education, especially for girls and children whose education has been disrupted by conflict; immunization, nutrition and growth-monitoring programmes; HIV/AIDS awareness and prevention training; and ongoing provision of emergency health, water and sanitation services.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>20-Nov-Header-1</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/nous-enfants-reporters-engages-pour-mettre-fin-aux-violences-faites-a-lenfant/20-nov-header-1/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 05 Dec 2013 10:41:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/20-Nov-Header-1.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[Le 28 Novembre était  la journée mondiale de L'Enfant et le 24ème anniversaire de la convention relative aux droits de l’enfant. Le thème était "mettre fin aux violences faites à l'enfant". ]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2189</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-12-05 10:41:25</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-12-05 10:41:25</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_metadata</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:5:{s:5:"width";i:621;s:6:"height";i:538;s:4:"file";s:40:"2013/12/Article-Sylvie_Synphorone-FD.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:2:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:40:"Article-Sylvie_Synphorone-FD-150x150.jpg";s:5:"width";i:150;s:6:"height";i:150;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}s:6:"medium";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:40:"Article-Sylvie_Synphorone-FD-300x259.jpg";s:5:"width";i:300;s:6:"height";i:259;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";d:14;s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:15:"Canon EOS 1000D";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:1384953361;s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";s:2:"55";s:3:"iso";s:4:"1600";s:13:"shutter_speed";s:8:"0.003125";s:5:"title";s:0:"";}}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Children gather to play and learn at one of the three Child Friendly Space (CFS) operated by UNICEF Education/Child Protection partner RHA in Punia. Offering a safe place to gather outside of school, the CFS can serve as a point of refuge and one in which to share and overcome that which they may have experienced in the course of conflict and displacement. Following heavy fighting in early 2013 between the Raia Mutomboki (RM) rebel group and the Congolese Army (FARDC) more than 55,000 people were displaced into the forests and indigenous villages of Punia Territory, Maniema Province, Democratic Republic of the Congo. Despite the logistical challenges of providing aid in an area inaccessible by car, and with persistent threats to security, UNICEF RRMP partner NRC immediately intervened to provide a multi-sectorial evaluation (MSA) allowing for a coordinated, rapid response between UN, INGO and Local NGO partners. By July, In addition to the rehabilitation/construction of 15 water sources, establishment of 22 water chlorination points and construction of 48 latrines, UNICEF partners succeeded in providing emergency non-food item (NFI) support to more then 5,700 households (approximately 28,000 people) emergency health services to more than 15,000 and Education / Child Protection support to the teachers and pupils of 65 separate schools in the affected area. With the area now largely under the control of the national authorities the vast majority of the population has returned home.</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/photo-de-la-semaine/children-gather-to-play-and-learn-at-one-of-the-three-child-friendly-space-cfs-operated-by-unicef-educationchild-protection-partner-rha-in-punia-offering-a-safe-place-to-gather-outside-of-school/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 06 Dec 2013 15:03:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Brett-Morton_Photo-of-the-Week_FD.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>children-gather-to-play-and-learn-at-one-of-the-three-child-friendly-space-cfs-operated-by-unicef-educationchild-protection-partner-rha-in-punia-offering-a-safe-place-to-gather-outside-of-school</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>

			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_metadata</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:5:{s:5:"width";i:617;s:6:"height";i:441;s:4:"file";s:45:"2013/12/Brett-Morton_Photo-of-the-Week_FD.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:2:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:45:"Brett-Morton_Photo-of-the-Week_FD-150x150.jpg";s:5:"width";i:150;s:6:"height";i:150;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}s:6:"medium";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:45:"Brett-Morton_Photo-of-the-Week_FD-300x214.jpg";s:5:"width";i:300;s:6:"height";i:214;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:12:"Brett Morton";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:1374684850;s:9:"copyright";s:24:"©UNICEF DRC/2013/Morton";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:1512:"Children gather to play and learn at one of the three Child Friendly Space (CFS) operated by UNICEF Education/Child Protection partner RHA in Punia. Offering a safe place to gather outside of school, the CFS can serve as a point of refuge and one in which to share and overcome that which they may have experienced in the course of conflict and displacement. 

Following heavy fighting in early 2013 between the Raia Mutomboki (RM) rebel group and the Congolese Army (FARDC) more than 55,000 people were displaced into the forests and indigenous villages of Punia Territory, Maniema Province, Democratic Republic of the Congo. 

Despite the logistical challenges of providing aid in an area inaccessible by car, and with persistent threats to security, UNICEF RRMP partner NRC immediately intervened to provide a multi-sectorial evaluation (MSA) allowing for a coordinated, rapid response between UN, INGO and Local NGO partners. 

By July, In addition to the rehabilitation/construction of 15 water sources, establishment of 22 water chlorination points and construction of 48 latrines, UNICEF partners succeeded in providing emergency non-food item (NFI) support to more then 5,700 households (approximately 28,000 people) emergency health services to more than 15,000 and Education / Child Protection support to the teachers and pupils of 65 separate schools in the affected area. 

With the area now largely under the control of the national authorities the vast majority of the population has returned home.";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>Children gather to observe the start of the three-day national vaccination campaign in the Mugunga 1 Internal Displacement Camp, North Kivu, DRC.Together with representatives of the DRC Ministry of Health, the WHO and local partners, UNICEF launched the North Kivu portion of the three-day National Polio Vaccination Campaign on July 11th at the Mugunga 1 Internal Displacement Camp outside Goma. Country-wide the vaccination campaign aims to immunize 16.3 million children aged 0-5 years against Polio, taking the occasion to also provide Vitamin A supplementation and deworming pills to the children and register children under 3 months with the civil authorities. Within North Kivu Province, the campaign has set out to immunize 1.3 million children.Since the launch in 1988 of the Global Initiative to Eradicate Polio, coordinated by the governments of countries concerned, WHO, UNICEF, Rotary International and the CDC-Atlanta, the 350,000 children paralyzed annually by Polio has been reduced by more than 99% while reducing the number of endemic countries from 125 to 3. Participating in the immunization campaigns since 1998, the DRC has seen a steady reduction of polio cases, and has now been polio-free since December 2011.</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/protection-2/children-gather-to-observe-the-start-of-the-three-day-national-vaccination-campaign-in-the-mugunga-1-internal-displacement-camp-north-kivu-drc-together-with-representatives-of-the-drc-ministry-of/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 06 Dec 2013 15:42:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/3.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>

		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-12-06 15:42:41</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>children-gather-to-observe-the-start-of-the-three-day-national-vaccination-campaign-in-the-mugunga-1-internal-displacement-camp-north-kivu-drc-together-with-representatives-of-the-drc-ministry-of</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>2374</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>

			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_metadata</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:5:{s:5:"width";i:844;s:6:"height";i:611;s:4:"file";s:13:"2013/12/3.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:2:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:13:"3-150x150.jpg";s:5:"width";i:150;s:6:"height";i:150;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}s:6:"medium";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:13:"3-300x217.jpg";s:5:"width";i:300;s:6:"height";i:217;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:12:"Brett Morton";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:1373537001;s:9:"copyright";s:29:"© UNICEF RDC / 2013 / Morton";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:1242:"Children gather to observe the start of the three-day national vaccination campaign in the Mugunga 1 Internal Displacement Camp, North Kivu, DRC.

Together with representatives of the DRC Ministry of Health, the WHO and local partners, UNICEF launched the North Kivu portion of the three-day National Polio Vaccination Campaign on July 11th at the Mugunga 1 Internal Displacement Camp outside Goma. 

Country-wide the vaccination campaign aims to immunize 16.3 million children aged 0-5 years against Polio, taking the occasion to also provide Vitamin A supplementation and deworming pills to the children and register children under 3 months with the civil authorities. Within North Kivu Province, the campaign has set out to immunize 1.3 million children.

Since the launch in 1988 of the Global Initiative to Eradicate Polio, coordinated by the governments of countries concerned, WHO, UNICEF, Rotary International and the CDC-Atlanta, the 350,000 children paralyzed annually by Polio has been reduced by more than 99% while reducing the number of endemic countries from 125 to 3. 

Participating in the immunization campaigns since 1998, the DRC has seen a steady reduction of polio cases, and has now been polio-free since December 2011.";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Following heavy fighting in early 2013 between the Raia Mutomboki (RM) rebel group and the Congolese Army (FARDC) more than 55,000 people were displaced into the forests and indigenous villages of Punia Territory, Maniema Province, Democratic Republic of the Congo. Despite the logistical challenges of providing aid in an area inaccessible by car, and with persistent threats to security, UNICEF RRMP partner NRC immediately intervened to provide a multi-sectorial evaluation (MSA) allowing for a coordinated, rapid response between UN, INGO and Local NGO partners. By July, In addition to the rehabilitation/construction of 15 water sources, establishment of 22 water chlorination points and construction of 48 latrines, UNICEF partners succeeded in providing emergency non-food item (NFI) support to more then 5,700 households (approximately 28,000 people) emergency health services to more than 15,000 and Education / Child Protection support to the teachers and pupils of 65 separate schools in the affected area. With the area now largely under the control of the national authorities the vast majority of the population has returned home.</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/protection-2/following-heavy-fighting-in-early-2013-between-the-raia-mutomboki-rm-rebel-group-and-the-congolese-army-fardc-more-than-55000-people-were-displaced-into-the-forests-and-indigenous-villages-of-pun/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 07 Dec 2013 10:09:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/8.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2432</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-12-07 10:09:29</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-12-07 10:09:29</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>following-heavy-fighting-in-early-2013-between-the-raia-mutomboki-rm-rebel-group-and-the-congolese-army-fardc-more-than-55000-people-were-displaced-into-the-forests-and-indigenous-villages-of-pun</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>2374</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>attachment</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>

Despite the logistical challenges of providing aid in an area inaccessible by car, and with persistent threats to security, UNICEF RRMP partner NRC immediately intervened to provide a multi-sectorial evaluation (MSA) allowing for a coordinated, rapid response between UN, INGO and Local NGO partners. 

By July, In addition to the rehabilitation/construction of 15 water sources, establishment of 22 water chlorination points and construction of 48 latrines, UNICEF partners succeeded in providing emergency non-food item (NFI) support to more then 5,700 households (approximately 28,000 people) emergency health services to more than 15,000 and Education / Child Protection support to the teachers and pupils of 65 separate schools in the affected area. 

With the area now largely under the control of the national authorities the vast majority of the population has returned home.";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>March 16, 2013Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRCUNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki  and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program ? co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando. From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families. Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners? relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations. Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This ?Fair Approach? represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.Agathe, 30, fled her home in Mwimbili village in February when fighting broke out between the Raia Mutomboki and FARDC. After returning briefly in March, she fled again with her husband and three children in April, seeking shelter with a host family in Mwenga Center. ?I?m really content with what I purchased,? Agathe explained of the basins, saucepans and clothing she purchased at the fair. ?Most importantly, I can now prepare food for the family.?</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/urgences/urgences-chiffres-clefs/march-16-2013kionvu-mwenga-south-kivu-drcunicef-rrmp-partner-avsi-carries-out-nfi-fair-since-late-2012-fighting-between-rebels-of-the-raia-mutomboki-and-the-congolese-army-fardc-has-lead-t/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 07 Dec 2013 11:30:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/20.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[March 16, 2013
Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRC
UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.

Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki  and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program – co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando. 

From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families. 

Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners’ relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations. 

Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This “Fair Approach” represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.

Agathe, 30, fled her home in Mwimbili village in February when fighting broke out between the Raia Mutomboki and FARDC. After returning briefly in March, she fled again with her husband and three children in April, seeking shelter with a host family in Mwenga Center. 

“I’m really content with what I purchased,” Agathe explained of the basins, saucepans and clothing she purchased at the fair. “Most importantly, I can now prepare food for the family.”]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2466</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-12-07 11:30:12</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-12-07 11:30:12</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>march-16-2013kionvu-mwenga-south-kivu-drcunicef-rrmp-partner-avsi-carries-out-nfi-fair-since-late-2012-fighting-between-rebels-of-the-raia-mutomboki-and-the-congolese-army-fardc-has-lead-t</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>2465</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>attachment</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:attachment_url>http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/20.jpg</wp:attachment_url>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_metadata</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:5:{s:5:"width";i:674;s:6:"height";i:539;s:4:"file";s:14:"2013/12/20.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:2:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:14:"20-150x150.jpg";s:5:"width";i:150;s:6:"height";i:150;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}s:6:"medium";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:14:"20-300x239.jpg";s:5:"width";i:300;s:6:"height";i:239;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:12:"Brett Morton";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:2534:"March 16, 2013
Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRC
UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.

Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki  and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program – co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando. 

From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families. 

Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners’ relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations. 

Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This “Fair Approach” represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.

Agathe, 30, fled her home in Mwimbili village in February when fighting broke out between the Raia Mutomboki and FARDC. After returning briefly in March, she fled again with her husband and three children in April, seeking shelter with a host family in Mwenga Center. 

“I’m really content with what I purchased,” Agathe explained of the basins, saucepans and clothing she purchased at the fair. “Most importantly, I can now prepare food for the family.”";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:1368701582;s:9:"copyright";s:24:"©UNICEF DRC/2013/Morton";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:2516:"March 16, 2013
Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRC
UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.

Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki  and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program ? co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando. 

From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families. 

Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners? relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations. 

Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This ?Fair Approach? represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.

Agathe, 30, fled her home in Mwimbili village in February when fighting broke out between the Raia Mutomboki and FARDC. After returning briefly in March, she fled again with her husband and three children in April, seeking shelter with a host family in Mwenga Center. 

?I?m really content with what I purchased,? Agathe explained of the basins, saucepans and clothing she purchased at the fair. ?Most importantly, I can now prepare food for the family.?";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>On August 16, 2013 UNICEF and Merlin, with the support of ECHO and UNHASS delivered 3.5 tons of medical/nutritional supplies to Nobili, North Kivu, DRC, as part of the OCHA/UNICEF led RRMP program. Following attacks on Kamongo by the ADF-Nalu rebels in July, more than 66,000 people were displaced from their homes in to surrounding villages in DRC and neighboring Uganda. RRMP assessments in late July revealed a 550% increase in child mortality and nearly 50% prevelance of diarrhea in children under 5. With many displaced settling in Nobili, approximately 9 km from Kamongo, the population more than tripled from 8,500 residents to 30,500. The hosiptal and health centers were looted during the attacks, leaving little resources to combat disease and malnutrition. Immediately following the distribution of supplies Merlin opened mobile health clinics in the area and began support to the hospital and area health centers, and together with UNICEF, the Ministry of Health and Lutheran World Federation (LWF) began a five-day measles vaccination campaign targeting more than 45,000 displaced and host-community children.</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/urgences/reponse-rapide-au-mouvement-de-population-rrmp/on-august-16-2013-unicef-and-merlin-with-the-support-of-echo-and-unhass-delivered-3-5-tons-of-medicalnutritional-supplies-to-nobili-north-kivu-drc-as-part-of-the-ochaunicef-led-rrmp-program-fo/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 07 Dec 2013 15:27:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/28.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2552</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-12-07 15:27:09</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-12-07 15:27:09</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>on-august-16-2013-unicef-and-merlin-with-the-support-of-echo-and-unhass-delivered-3-5-tons-of-medicalnutritional-supplies-to-nobili-north-kivu-drc-as-part-of-the-ochaunicef-led-rrmp-program-fo</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>1853</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>attachment</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>

Following attacks on Kamongo by the ADF-Nalu rebels in July, more than 66,000 people were displaced from their homes in to surrounding villages in DRC and neighboring Uganda. RRMP assessments in late July revealed a 550% increase in child mortality and nearly 50% prevelance of diarrhea in children under 5. With many displaced settling in Nobili, approximately 9 km from Kamongo, the population more than tripled from 8,500 residents to 30,500. The hosiptal and health centers were looted during the attacks, leaving little resources to combat disease and malnutrition. Immediately following the distribution of supplies Merlin opened mobile health clinics in the area and began support to the hospital and area health centers, and together with UNICEF, the Ministry of Health and Lutheran World Federation (LWF) began a five-day measles vaccination campaign targeting more than 45,000 displaced and host-community children.";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

		<title>eva</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/eau-et-assainissement-2/villages-et-ecoles-assainies/eva/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 07 Dec 2013 15:56:09 +0000</pubDate>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/eva.jpg</guid>

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2563</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-12-07 15:56:09</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-12-07 15:56:09</wp:post_date_gmt>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_metadata</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:5:{s:5:"width";i:1311;s:6:"height";i:447;s:4:"file";s:15:"2013/12/eva.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:3:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:15:"eva-150x150.jpg";s:5:"width";i:150;s:6:"height";i:150;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}s:6:"medium";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:15:"eva-300x102.jpg";s:5:"width";i:300;s:6:"height";i:102;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}s:5:"large";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:16:"eva-1024x349.jpg";s:5:"width";i:1024;s:6:"height";i:349;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:0;s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:0:"";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>March 16, 2013Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRCUNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki  and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program ? co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando. From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families. Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners? relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations. Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This ?Fair Approach? represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.Agathe, 30, fled her home in Mwimbili village in February when fighting broke out between the Raia Mutomboki and FARDC. After returning briefly in March, she fled again with her husband and three children in April, seeking shelter with a host family in Mwenga Center. ?I?m really content with what I purchased,? Agathe explained of the basins, saucepans and clothing she purchased at the fair. ?Most importantly, I can now prepare food for the family.?</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/eau-et-assainissement-2/villages-et-ecoles-assainies/march-16-2013kionvu-mwenga-south-kivu-drcunicef-rrmp-partner-avsi-carries-out-nfi-fair-since-late-2012-fighting-between-rebels-of-the-raia-mutomboki-and-the-congolese-army-fardc-has-lead-t-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 07 Dec 2013 16:01:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/30.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[March 16, 2013
Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRC
UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.

Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki  and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program – co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando. 

From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families. 

Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners’ relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations. 

Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This “Fair Approach” represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.

Agathe, 30, fled her home in Mwimbili village in February when fighting broke out between the Raia Mutomboki and FARDC. After returning briefly in March, she fled again with her husband and three children in April, seeking shelter with a host family in Mwenga Center. 

“I’m really content with what I purchased,” Agathe explained of the basins, saucepans and clothing she purchased at the fair. “Most importantly, I can now prepare food for the family.”]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>

Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRC
UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.

Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki  and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program – co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando. 

From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families. 

Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners’ relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations. 

Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This “Fair Approach” represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.

Agathe, 30, fled her home in Mwimbili village in February when fighting broke out between the Raia Mutomboki and FARDC. After returning briefly in March, she fled again with her husband and three children in April, seeking shelter with a host family in Mwenga Center. 

“I’m really content with what I purchased,” Agathe explained of the basins, saucepans and clothing she purchased at the fair. “Most importantly, I can now prepare food for the family.”";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:1368696630;s:9:"copyright";s:24:"©UNICEF DRC/2013/Morton";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:2516:"March 16, 2013
Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRC
UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.

Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki  and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program ? co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando. 

From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families. 

Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners? relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations. 

Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This ?Fair Approach? represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.

Agathe, 30, fled her home in Mwimbili village in February when fighting broke out between the Raia Mutomboki and FARDC. After returning briefly in March, she fled again with her husband and three children in April, seeking shelter with a host family in Mwenga Center. 

?I?m really content with what I purchased,? Agathe explained of the basins, saucepans and clothing she purchased at the fair. ?Most importantly, I can now prepare food for the family.?";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>DRC Sitrep 15 Oct-23 Nov 2013 EXTERNAL Final</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/rapport-de-situation-octobre-2013-2/drc-sitrep-15-oct-23-nov-2013-external-final/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 07 Dec 2013 16:07:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/DRC-Sitrep-15-Oct-23-Nov-2013-EXTERNAL-Final.pdf</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2576</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-12-07 16:07:33</wp:post_date>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attached_file</wp:meta_key>

	<item>
		<title>Children play at the Child Friendly Space (CFS) operated by UNICEF partner AVSI in the Bulengo IDP site. The CFS provide a safe environment for children to gather for recreational and educational activities while not in school.A delegation of Emergency Directors including UNICEF Director of Emergency Programs Ted Chaiban, OCHA Operations Director John Ging, UN Humanitarian Coordinator in DRC Moustapha Soumare and high-level representatives from WFP, WHO, FAO and UNHCR visited the Bulengo Spontaneous Site just outside Goma on Tuesday, October 22, 2013 to witness the multi-agency humanitarian response in the largest single displacement site in North Kivu. Home to approximately 55,000 Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) Bulengo has experienced a massive influx of IDPs since November 2012 when thousands fled towards Goma during fighting between the M23 and Congolese Army (FARDC). Since then, numerous waves of displacement have resulted from clashes between the FARDC and M23, Nyatura and APCLS rebel groups. Coming mainly from the Masisi and Rutshuru territories, the IDPs in Bulengo represent some of the more than 1 million currently displaced in North Kivu. Coordinated by IOM and managed by Première Urgence ? Aide Médicale International (PU-AMI) and Danish Refugee Council (DRC) residents of the Bulengo Site have received Non-Food Item (NFI) support  from the UNICEF-OCHA RRMP in December 2012, Food and Nutrition support from WFP and World Vision, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) support from Oxfam and Mercy Corps, Education and Child Protection support from UNICEF partner AVSI and Health support from MSF Belgium.</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/rapport-de-situation-octobre-2013-2/children-play-at-the-child-friendly-space-cfs-operated-by-unicef-partner-avsi-in-the-bulengo-idp-site-the-cfs-provide-a-safe-environment-for-children-to-gather-for-recreational-and-educational-acti/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 07 Dec 2013 16:08:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Sitrep.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Children play at the Child Friendly Space (CFS) operated by UNICEF partner AVSI in the Bulengo IDP site. The CFS provide a safe environment for children to gather for recreational and educational activities while not in school.

A delegation of Emergency Directors including UNICEF Director of Emergency Programs Ted Chaiban, OCHA Operations Director John Ging, UN Humanitarian Coordinator in DRC Moustapha Soumare and high-level representatives from WFP, WHO, FAO and UNHCR visited the Bulengo Spontaneous Site just outside Goma on Tuesday, October 22, 2013 to witness the multi-agency humanitarian response in the largest single displacement site in North Kivu. 

Home to approximately 55,000 Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) Bulengo has experienced a massive influx of IDPs since November 2012 when thousands fled towards Goma during fighting between the M23 and Congolese Army (FARDC). Since then, numerous waves of displacement have resulted from clashes between the FARDC and M23, Nyatura and APCLS rebel groups. Coming mainly from the Masisi and Rutshuru territories, the IDPs in Bulengo represent some of the more than 1 million currently displaced in North Kivu. 

Coordinated by IOM and managed by Première Urgence – Aide Médicale International (PU-AMI) and Danish Refugee Council (DRC) residents of the Bulengo Site have received Non-Food Item (NFI) support  from the UNICEF-OCHA RRMP in December 2012, Food and Nutrition support from WFP and World Vision, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) support from Oxfam and Mercy Corps, Education and Child Protection support from UNICEF partner AVSI and Health support from MSF Belgium.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2577</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-12-07 16:08:55</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-12-07 16:08:55</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>children-play-at-the-child-friendly-space-cfs-operated-by-unicef-partner-avsi-in-the-bulengo-idp-site-the-cfs-provide-a-safe-environment-for-children-to-gather-for-recreational-and-educational-acti</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>2574</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>attachment</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:attachment_url>http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Sitrep.jpg</wp:attachment_url>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attached_file</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2013/12/Sitrep.jpg]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_metadata</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:5:{s:5:"width";i:647;s:6:"height";i:462;s:4:"file";s:18:"2013/12/Sitrep.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:2:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:18:"Sitrep-150x150.jpg";s:5:"width";i:150;s:6:"height";i:150;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}s:6:"medium";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:18:"Sitrep-300x214.jpg";s:5:"width";i:300;s:6:"height";i:214;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:12:"Brett Morton";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:1648:"Children play at the Child Friendly Space (CFS) operated by UNICEF partner AVSI in the Bulengo IDP site. The CFS provide a safe environment for children to gather for recreational and educational activities while not in school.

A delegation of Emergency Directors including UNICEF Director of Emergency Programs Ted Chaiban, OCHA Operations Director John Ging, UN Humanitarian Coordinator in DRC Moustapha Soumare and high-level representatives from WFP, WHO, FAO and UNHCR visited the Bulengo Spontaneous Site just outside Goma on Tuesday, October 22, 2013 to witness the multi-agency humanitarian response in the largest single displacement site in North Kivu. 

Home to approximately 55,000 Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) Bulengo has experienced a massive influx of IDPs since November 2012 when thousands fled towards Goma during fighting between the M23 and Congolese Army (FARDC). Since then, numerous waves of displacement have resulted from clashes between the FARDC and M23, Nyatura and APCLS rebel groups. Coming mainly from the Masisi and Rutshuru territories, the IDPs in Bulengo represent some of the more than 1 million currently displaced in North Kivu. 

Coordinated by IOM and managed by Première Urgence – Aide Médicale International (PU-AMI) and Danish Refugee Council (DRC) residents of the Bulengo Site have received Non-Food Item (NFI) support  from the UNICEF-OCHA RRMP in December 2012, Food and Nutrition support from WFP and World Vision, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) support from Oxfam and Mercy Corps, Education and Child Protection support from UNICEF partner AVSI and Health support from MSF Belgium.";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:1382454622;s:9:"copyright";s:25:"© UNICEF RDC/2013/Morton";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:1646:"Children play at the Child Friendly Space (CFS) operated by UNICEF partner AVSI in the Bulengo IDP site. The CFS provide a safe environment for children to gather for recreational and educational activities while not in school.

A delegation of Emergency Directors including UNICEF Director of Emergency Programs Ted Chaiban, OCHA Operations Director John Ging, UN Humanitarian Coordinator in DRC Moustapha Soumare and high-level representatives from WFP, WHO, FAO and UNHCR visited the Bulengo Spontaneous Site just outside Goma on Tuesday, October 22, 2013 to witness the multi-agency humanitarian response in the largest single displacement site in North Kivu. 

Home to approximately 55,000 Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) Bulengo has experienced a massive influx of IDPs since November 2012 when thousands fled towards Goma during fighting between the M23 and Congolese Army (FARDC). Since then, numerous waves of displacement have resulted from clashes between the FARDC and M23, Nyatura and APCLS rebel groups. Coming mainly from the Masisi and Rutshuru territories, the IDPs in Bulengo represent some of the more than 1 million currently displaced in North Kivu. 

Coordinated by IOM and managed by Première Urgence ? Aide Médicale International (PU-AMI) and Danish Refugee Council (DRC) residents of the Bulengo Site have received Non-Food Item (NFI) support  from the UNICEF-OCHA RRMP in December 2012, Food and Nutrition support from WFP and World Vision, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) support from Oxfam and Mercy Corps, Education and Child Protection support from UNICEF partner AVSI and Health support from MSF Belgium.";}}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>

	<item>
		<title>rrmp</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/urgences/reponse-rapide-au-mouvement-de-population-rrmp/rrmp/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 Dec 2013 10:31:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/rrmp.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2717</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-12-09 10:31:40</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-12-09 10:31:40</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>rrmp</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>1853</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>attachment</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:attachment_url>http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/rrmp.jpg</wp:attachment_url>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attached_file</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2013/11/rrmp.jpg]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_metadata</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:5:{s:5:"width";i:1345;s:6:"height";i:149;s:4:"file";s:16:"2013/11/rrmp.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:3:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:16:"rrmp-150x149.jpg";s:5:"width";i:150;s:6:"height";i:149;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}s:6:"medium";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:15:"rrmp-300x33.jpg";s:5:"width";i:300;s:6:"height";i:33;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}s:5:"large";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:17:"rrmp-1024x113.jpg";s:5:"width";i:1024;s:6:"height";i:113;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:0;s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:0:"";}}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>On August 16, 2013 UNICEF and Merlin, with the support of ECHO and UNHASS delivered 3.5 tons of medical/nutritional supplies to Nobili, North Kivu, DRC, as part of the OCHA/UNICEF led RRMP program. Following attacks on Kamongo by the ADF-Nalu rebels in July, more than 66,000 people were displaced from their homes in to surrounding villages in DRC and neighboring Uganda. RRMP assessments in late July revealed a 550% increase in child mortality and nearly 50% prevelance of diarrhea in children under 5. With many displaced settling in Nobili, approximately 9 km from Kamongo, the population more than tripled from 8,500 residents to 30,500. The hosiptal and health centers were looted during the attacks, leaving little resources to combat disease and malnutrition. Immediately following the distribution of supplies Merlin opened mobile health clinics in the area and began support to the hospital and area health centers, and together with UNICEF, the Ministry of Health and Lutheran World Federation (LWF) began a five-day measles vaccination campaign targeting more than 45,000 displaced and host-community children.</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/urgences/reponse-rapide-au-mouvement-de-population-rrmp/on-august-16-2013-unicef-and-merlin-with-the-support-of-echo-and-unhass-delivered-3-5-tons-of-medicalnutritional-supplies-to-nobili-north-kivu-drc-as-part-of-the-ochaunicef-led-rrmp-program-fo-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 Dec 2013 10:33:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/rrmp23.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2718</wp:post_id>

Following attacks on Kamongo by the ADF-Nalu rebels in July, more than 66,000 people were displaced from their homes in to surrounding villages in DRC and neighboring Uganda. RRMP assessments in late July revealed a 550% increase in child mortality and nearly 50% prevelance of diarrhea in children under 5. With many displaced settling in Nobili, approximately 9 km from Kamongo, the population more than tripled from 8,500 residents to 30,500. The hosiptal and health centers were looted during the attacks, leaving little resources to combat disease and malnutrition. Immediately following the distribution of supplies Merlin opened mobile health clinics in the area and began support to the hospital and area health centers, and together with UNICEF, the Ministry of Health and Lutheran World Federation (LWF) began a five-day measles vaccination campaign targeting more than 45,000 displaced and host-community children.";}}]]></wp:meta_value>
