	<item>
		<title>Profil bloggeur_Brett Morton</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/nosbloggers/profil-bloggeur_brett-morton/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 Dec 2013 16:49:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Profil-bloggeur_Brett-Morton.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[March 15, 2013
Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRC
UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.

Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki  and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program – co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando. 

From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families. 

Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners’ relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations. 

Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This “Fair Approach” represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2810</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-12-09 16:49:14</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-12-09 16:49:14</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>profil-bloggeur_brett-morton</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>2783</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>attachment</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:attachment_url>http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Profil-bloggeur_Brett-Morton.jpg</wp:attachment_url>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attached_file</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2013/12/Profil-bloggeur_Brett-Morton.jpg]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_metadata</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:5:{s:5:"width";i:591;s:6:"height";i:591;s:4:"file";s:40:"2013/12/Profil-bloggeur_Brett-Morton.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:2:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:40:"Profil-bloggeur_Brett-Morton-150x150.jpg";s:5:"width";i:150;s:6:"height";i:150;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}s:6:"medium";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:40:"Profil-bloggeur_Brett-Morton-300x300.jpg";s:5:"width";i:300;s:6:"height";i:300;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:12:"Brett Morton";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:2068:"March 15, 2013
Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRC
UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.

Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki  and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program – co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando. 

From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families. 

Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners’ relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations. 

Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This “Fair Approach” represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:1368635248;s:9:"copyright";s:29:"© UNICEF RDC / 2013 / Morton";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:0:"";}}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>

	<item>
		<title>Profil bloggeur_Ndiaga Seck</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/nosbloggers/profil-bloggeur_ndiaga-seck/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 Dec 2013 17:01:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Profil-bloggeur_Ndiaga-Seck.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Sotraki Temporary Site, Goma… 8th CEPAC, a local NGO operating in Goma distributes BP-5 buscuits and Plumpy nut to malnourished children living in the Sotraki site… Following months of relative peace after the takeover of Goma by the M23 rebels in November, 2012, fighting once again broke out on the edge of Goma between the M23 and the Congolese Army (FARDC) in May, 2013. Upwards of 6,000 people fled their homes towards the city center, where they sought shelter in schools, churches, or with host families.

In response to the displacement the humanitarian community mobilized resources to create numerous temporary sites to cater to the displaced. UNICEF coordinated with partners Norwegian  Refugee Council (NRC) and Norwegian Church Aid (NCA) to provide shelter and Water, Sanitation and Hygiene as well as logistical support to the management of the sites. 

With more than 1,700 families staying at the Sotraki site (as of 04 June, 2013) UNICEF partner NCA responded within one week of the displacement to construct 16 latrines,12 showers, and instal a 30m3 water bladder which provides a constant flow to 12 taps in the site. In addition, NCA hygiene teams have organized and supervised the regular cleaning of the latrines, as well as spreading general hygiene messages.
NRC has contributed to the establishment of numerous tents in which to hose the displaced in both the Sotraki and Buhimba sites. In addition, through UNICEF RRMP funds, NRC has provided transportation of displaced to the Buhimba site in an effort to decongest the Sotraki site. 
Plans are underway for an NFI distribution to be carried out through UNICEF RRMP partners NRC and Slidarités International.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>UNICEF Deputy Representative Sylvie Fouet visits PEAR+ (Programme Elargi d?Assistance aux Retours) activities in the Matanda area of South Kivu.PEAR Plus provides an integrated package of assistance and capacity building to communities; local and state authorities in the sectors of Health, Water, Hygiene and Sanitation, Education and Child Protection.Sectorial specific activities include the following: School reconstruction, support to transparent and equitable structure management, teacher-training, support to parent/teacher associations, provision of education kits and didactic material. Restoration and development of sustainable access to safe water and healthy environment; rehabilitation of health centres, reinforcement of health staff and directors? capacities; provision of basic medical necessities; support to vaccination campaigns and community-based treatment for malnutrition as well as the identification and strengthening child protection networks and responses are all part of the Programme.  Accompanied by peacebuilding activities and interventions designed to improve social cohesion, emphasis is put on governance activities (linked to social service provision) and conflict risk reduction in order to keep the Programme relevant to the evolving context and consequent needs. Increased community participation and ownership, as well as a reinforcement of the social contract between community, local and state authorities are increasingly key outputs of PEAR+?s approach.  A more explicit relationship with UNICEF?s long term programming provides a clear exit strategy and guarantees a degree of sustainability in the medium term, whilst a closer alignment with UNICEF?s emergency response mechanisms and the integration of sectorial emergency preparedness helps improve community resilience to the impact of conflict.  In recognition of the fluid nature in the east, the objective is to develop a way of working which supports social and economic rehabilitation; reinforces community resilience and eases the transition to emergency assistance or longer term support.</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/nosbloggers/unicef-deputy-representative-sylvie-fouet-visits-pear-programme-elargi-dassistance-aux-retours-activities-in-the-matanda-area-of-south-kivu-pear-plus-provides-an-integrated-package-of-assistance/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 Dec 2013 17:10:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Profil-bloggeur_Sylvie-Fouet2.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[UNICEF Deputy Representative Sylvie Fouet visits PEAR+ (Programme Elargi d’Assistance aux Retours) activities in the Matanda area of South Kivu.

PEAR Plus provides an integrated package of assistance and capacity building to communities; local and state authorities in the sectors of Health, Water, Hygiene and Sanitation, Education and Child Protection.Sectorial specific activities include the following: School reconstruction, support to transparent and equitable structure management, teacher-training, support to parent/teacher associations, provision of education kits and didactic material. Restoration and development of sustainable access to safe water and healthy environment; rehabilitation of health centres, reinforcement of health staff and directors’ capacities; provision of basic medical necessities; support to vaccination campaigns and community-based treatment for malnutrition as well as the identification and strengthening child protection networks and responses are all part of the Programme.  

Accompanied by peacebuilding activities and interventions designed to improve social cohesion, emphasis is put on governance activities (linked to social service provision) and conflict risk reduction in order to keep the Programme relevant to the evolving context and consequent needs. Increased community participation and ownership, as well as a reinforcement of the social contract between community, local and state authorities are increasingly key outputs of PEAR+’s approach.  

A more explicit relationship with UNICEF’s long term programming provides a clear exit strategy and guarantees a degree of sustainability in the medium term, whilst a closer alignment with UNICEF’s emergency response mechanisms and the integration of sectorial emergency preparedness helps improve community resilience to the impact of conflict.  In recognition of the fluid nature in the east, the objective is to develop a way of working which supports social and economic rehabilitation; reinforces community resilience and eases the transition to emergency assistance or longer term support.]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Profil Jonathan</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/nosbloggers/profil-jonathan/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 Dec 2013 17:16:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Profil-Jonathan.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2818</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-12-09 17:16:31</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-12-09 17:16:31</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>profil-jonathan</wp:post_name>

		<wp:post_type>attachment</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:attachment_url>http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Profil-Jonathan.jpg</wp:attachment_url>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attached_file</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2013/12/Profil-Jonathan.jpg]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_metadata</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:5:{s:5:"width";i:622;s:6:"height";i:415;s:4:"file";s:27:"2013/12/Profil-Jonathan.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:2:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:27:"Profil-Jonathan-150x150.jpg";s:5:"width";i:150;s:6:"height";i:150;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}s:6:"medium";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:27:"Profil-Jonathan-300x200.jpg";s:5:"width";i:300;s:6:"height";i:200;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";d:10;s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:15:"Canon EOS 1000D";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:1350144479;s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";s:2:"55";s:3:"iso";s:3:"200";s:13:"shutter_speed";s:7:"0.00625";s:5:"title";s:0:"";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>March 15, 2013Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRCUNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki  and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program ? co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando. From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families. Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners? relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations. Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This ?Fair Approach? represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/nosbloggers/march-15-2013kionvu-mwenga-south-kivu-drcunicef-rrmp-partner-avsi-carries-out-nfi-fair-since-late-2012-fighting-between-rebels-of-the-raia-mutomboki-and-the-congolese-army-fardc-has-lead-t/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 10 Dec 2013 09:30:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Profil-bloggeur_Brett-Morton2.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[March 15, 2013
Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRC
UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.

Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki  and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program – co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando. 

From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families. 

Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners’ relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations. 

Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This “Fair Approach” represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>March 15, 2013Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRCUNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki  and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program ? co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando. From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families. Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners? relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations. Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This ?Fair Approach? represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/nosbloggers/march-15-2013kionvu-mwenga-south-kivu-drcunicef-rrmp-partner-avsi-carries-out-nfi-fair-since-late-2012-fighting-between-rebels-of-the-raia-mutomboki-and-the-congolese-army-fardc-has-lead-t-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 10 Dec 2013 10:00:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Profil-bloggeur_Brett-Morton21.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[March 15, 2013
Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRC
UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.

Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki  and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program – co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando. 

From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families. 

Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners’ relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations. 

Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This “Fair Approach” represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>1</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/un-jour-historique-pour-la-sante-en-rdc/1-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 16 Dec 2013 13:18:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/12.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>

	<item>
		<title>NFI Header</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/rrmp-echo-continue-de-soutenir-lunicef-et-ocha-pour-les-foires-en-articles-menagers-essentiels/nfi-header/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 27 Dec 2013 08:58:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/NFI-Header.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[IRC DRC RRMP WaSH Intervention. 13 March, 2013. - -Mwateganyi, 45, married mother of 4 children – Agnes, 15 – Namwigima, 10 – Faida, 5 – Bulonza, 1 
-Displaced since January 5th from Maziba (towards Luntukulu) when fighting broke out between RM and FARDC
-This is the 5th time they’ve been displaced. First time was in ’98. In 2002 it was MaiMai vs. RCD.
-Staying in the home of Zihalirwa, who has hosted them each of the times they’ve been displaced as he is a family friend.
-“When we heard the shots we fled fearing for our lives. We had to leave everything behind, and took only the little we could carry immediately.”
-They left on foot, walking for about one day to cover the 15-20 km.
-The first difficulty is always the stress of dying. And then the risks along the route. The sickness of the children is a problem also. All the children fell sick by the time we arrived. 
-In Maziba they are farmers.
-“When we return home we already know everything will be missing or destroyed. The last time they even took the doors of the house.”
-“Here the big need is to find food. And clothes. And cooking utensils, and jerrycans. And the health of the children is very difficult.”
-The NFI kit is very important. We can use the sheeting when we return to use as a roof. The husband has already returned to begin rebuilding. The blanked and mat are good to have here and upon return. With the clothes the children can go to church. The pots and pans are so helpful because before we had to wait for others to finish using the pots and pans before we could start cooking. For everything else it was necessary to rely on the kindness of others to give us, but they don’t have much so it is difficult for them to give.
-The water source is very important. Before we had the latrine all the children had diarrhea. We had to wait for 1-2 hours at the water point to fetch water because of the crowds. Now there are no crowds.
-Ziahlirwa explains that as a host family it becomes very difficult for him also because they have little to give. 
-This is the first time they have received any aid with the displaced.
-“Thanks to the displaced I now have a latrine and clean water! I never had a proper latrine before, so it’s very nice.”
-When asked why he hosts the displaced, ZIahlirwa explained that “ One day I could also be displaced.”]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>5</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/les-enfants-reporters-reagissent-aux-evenements-du-lundi-30-decembre-a-kinshasa/5-4/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 31 Dec 2013 13:10:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/53.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>3412</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-12-31 13:10:30</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-12-31 13:10:30</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>5-4</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>3401</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>attachment</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

	<item>
		<title>1</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/les-enfants-reporters-reagissent-aux-evenements-du-lundi-30-decembre-a-kinshasa/1-3/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 31 Dec 2013 13:11:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/19.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>3420</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-12-31 13:11:41</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-12-31 13:11:41</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>1-3</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>3401</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>attachment</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:attachment_url>http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/19.jpg</wp:attachment_url>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attached_file</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2013/12/19.jpg]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<title>2UNICEF RDC 2013 3000 Amis</title>

	<item>
		<title>UNICEF Deputy Representative Sylvie Fouet visits PEAR+ (Programme Elargi d?Assistance aux Retours) activities in the Matanda area of South Kivu.PEAR Plus provides an integrated package of assistance and capacity building to communities; local and state authorities in the sectors of Health, Water, Hygiene and Sanitation, Education and Child Protection.Sectorial specific activities include the following: School reconstruction, support to transparent and equitable structure management, teacher-training, support to parent/teacher associations, provision of education kits and didactic material. Restoration and development of sustainable access to safe water and healthy environment; rehabilitation of health centres, reinforcement of health staff and directors? capacities; provision of basic medical necessities; support to vaccination campaigns and community-based treatment for malnutrition as well as the identification and strengthening child protection networks and responses are all part of the Programme.  Accompanied by peacebuilding activities and interventions designed to improve social cohesion, emphasis is put on governance activities (linked to social service provision) and conflict risk reduction in order to keep the Programme relevant to the evolving context and consequent needs. Increased community participation and ownership, as well as a reinforcement of the social contract between community, local and state authorities are increasingly key outputs of PEAR+?s approach.  A more explicit relationship with UNICEF?s long term programming provides a clear exit strategy and guarantees a degree of sustainability in the medium term, whilst a closer alignment with UNICEF?s emergency response mechanisms and the integration of sectorial emergency preparedness helps improve community resilience to the impact of conflict.  In recognition of the fluid nature in the east, the objective is to develop a way of working which supports social and economic rehabilitation; reinforces community resilience and eases the transition to emergency assistance or longer term support.</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/nosbloggers/unicef-deputy-representative-sylvie-fouet-visits-pear-programme-elargi-dassistance-aux-retours-activities-in-the-matanda-area-of-south-kivu-pear-plus-provides-an-integrated-package-of-assistance-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 31 Dec 2013 14:05:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Profil-bloggeur_Sylvie-Fouet-w.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[UNICEF Deputy Representative Sylvie Fouet visits PEAR+ (Programme Elargi d’Assistance aux Retours) activities in the Matanda area of South Kivu.

PEAR Plus provides an integrated package of assistance and capacity building to communities; local and state authorities in the sectors of Health, Water, Hygiene and Sanitation, Education and Child Protection.Sectorial specific activities include the following: School reconstruction, support to transparent and equitable structure management, teacher-training, support to parent/teacher associations, provision of education kits and didactic material. Restoration and development of sustainable access to safe water and healthy environment; rehabilitation of health centres, reinforcement of health staff and directors’ capacities; provision of basic medical necessities; support to vaccination campaigns and community-based treatment for malnutrition as well as the identification and strengthening child protection networks and responses are all part of the Programme.  

Accompanied by peacebuilding activities and interventions designed to improve social cohesion, emphasis is put on governance activities (linked to social service provision) and conflict risk reduction in order to keep the Programme relevant to the evolving context and consequent needs. Increased community participation and ownership, as well as a reinforcement of the social contract between community, local and state authorities are increasingly key outputs of PEAR+’s approach.  

A more explicit relationship with UNICEF’s long term programming provides a clear exit strategy and guarantees a degree of sustainability in the medium term, whilst a closer alignment with UNICEF’s emergency response mechanisms and the integration of sectorial emergency preparedness helps improve community resilience to the impact of conflict.  In recognition of the fluid nature in the east, the objective is to develop a way of working which supports social and economic rehabilitation; reinforces community resilience and eases the transition to emergency assistance or longer term support.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>3437</wp:post_id>

PEAR Plus provides an integrated package of assistance and capacity building to communities; local and state authorities in the sectors of Health, Water, Hygiene and Sanitation, Education and Child Protection.Sectorial specific activities include the following: School reconstruction, support to transparent and equitable structure management, teacher-training, support to parent/teacher associations, provision of education kits and didactic material. Restoration and development of sustainable access to safe water and healthy environment; rehabilitation of health centres, reinforcement of health staff and directors’ capacities; provision of basic medical necessities; support to vaccination campaigns and community-based treatment for malnutrition as well as the identification and strengthening child protection networks and responses are all part of the Programme.  

Accompanied by peacebuilding activities and interventions designed to improve social cohesion, emphasis is put on governance activities (linked to social service provision) and conflict risk reduction in order to keep the Programme relevant to the evolving context and consequent needs. Increased community participation and ownership, as well as a reinforcement of the social contract between community, local and state authorities are increasingly key outputs of PEAR+’s approach.  

A more explicit relationship with UNICEF’s long term programming provides a clear exit strategy and guarantees a degree of sustainability in the medium term, whilst a closer alignment with UNICEF’s emergency response mechanisms and the integration of sectorial emergency preparedness helps improve community resilience to the impact of conflict.  In recognition of the fluid nature in the east, the objective is to develop a way of working which supports social and economic rehabilitation; reinforces community resilience and eases the transition to emergency assistance or longer term support.";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:1384425635;s:9:"copyright";s:25:"© UNICEF RDC/2013/Morton";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:2102:"UNICEF Deputy Representative Sylvie Fouet visits PEAR+ (Programme Elargi d?Assistance aux Retours) activities in the Matanda area of South Kivu.

PEAR Plus provides an integrated package of assistance and capacity building to communities; local and state authorities in the sectors of Health, Water, Hygiene and Sanitation, Education and Child Protection.Sectorial specific activities include the following: School reconstruction, support to transparent and equitable structure management, teacher-training, support to parent/teacher associations, provision of education kits and didactic material. Restoration and development of sustainable access to safe water and healthy environment; rehabilitation of health centres, reinforcement of health staff and directors? capacities; provision of basic medical necessities; support to vaccination campaigns and community-based treatment for malnutrition as well as the identification and strengthening child protection networks and responses are all part of the Programme.  

Accompanied by peacebuilding activities and interventions designed to improve social cohesion, emphasis is put on governance activities (linked to social service provision) and conflict risk reduction in order to keep the Programme relevant to the evolving context and consequent needs. Increased community participation and ownership, as well as a reinforcement of the social contract between community, local and state authorities are increasingly key outputs of PEAR+?s approach.  

A more explicit relationship with UNICEF?s long term programming provides a clear exit strategy and guarantees a degree of sustainability in the medium term, whilst a closer alignment with UNICEF?s emergency response mechanisms and the integration of sectorial emergency preparedness helps improve community resilience to the impact of conflict.  In recognition of the fluid nature in the east, the objective is to develop a way of working which supports social and economic rehabilitation; reinforces community resilience and eases the transition to emergency assistance or longer term support.";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>Sotraki Temporary Site, Goma? 8th CEPAC, a local NGO operating in Goma distributes BP-5 buscuits and Plumpy nut to malnourished children living in the Sotraki site? Following months of relative peace after the takeover of Goma by the M23 rebels in November, 2012, fighting once again broke out on the edge of Goma between the M23 and the Congolese Army (FARDC) in May, 2013. Upwards of 6,000 people fled their homes towards the city center, where they sought shelter in schools, churches, or with host families.In response to the displacement the humanitarian community mobilized resources to create numerous temporary sites to cater to the displaced. UNICEF coordinated with partners Norwegian  Refugee Council (NRC) and Norwegian Church Aid (NCA) to provide shelter and Water, Sanitation and Hygiene as well as logistical support to the management of the sites. With more than 1,700 families staying at the Sotraki site (as of 04 June, 2013) UNICEF partner NCA responded within one week of the displacement to construct 16 latrines,12 showers, and instal a 30m3 water bladder which provides a constant flow to 12 taps in the site. In addition, NCA hygiene teams have organized and supervised the regular cleaning of the latrines, as well as spreading general hygiene messages.NRC has contributed to the establishment of numerous tents in which to hose the displaced in both the Sotraki and Buhimba sites. In addition, through UNICEF RRMP funds, NRC has provided transportation of displaced to the Buhimba site in an effort to decongest the Sotraki site. Plans are underway for an NFI distribution to be carried out through UNICEF RRMP partners NRC and Slidarités International.</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/photo-de-la-semaine-10-janvier-2014/sotraki-temporary-site-goma-8th-cepac-a-local-ngo-operating-in-goma-distributes-bp-5-buscuits-and-plumpy-nut-to-malnourished-children-living-in-the-sotraki-site-following-months-of-relative-peace/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 10 Jan 2014 14:55:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/130531120342.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Sotraki Temporary Site, Goma… 8th CEPAC, a local NGO operating in Goma distributes BP-5 buscuits and Plumpy nut to malnourished children living in the Sotraki site… Following months of relative peace after the takeover of Goma by the M23 rebels in November, 2012, fighting once again broke out on the edge of Goma between the M23 and the Congolese Army (FARDC) in May, 2013. Upwards of 6,000 people fled their homes towards the city center, where they sought shelter in schools, churches, or with host families.

In response to the displacement the humanitarian community mobilized resources to create numerous temporary sites to cater to the displaced. UNICEF coordinated with partners Norwegian  Refugee Council (NRC) and Norwegian Church Aid (NCA) to provide shelter and Water, Sanitation and Hygiene as well as logistical support to the management of the sites. 

With more than 1,700 families staying at the Sotraki site (as of 04 June, 2013) UNICEF partner NCA responded within one week of the displacement to construct 16 latrines,12 showers, and instal a 30m3 water bladder which provides a constant flow to 12 taps in the site. In addition, NCA hygiene teams have organized and supervised the regular cleaning of the latrines, as well as spreading general hygiene messages.
NRC has contributed to the establishment of numerous tents in which to hose the displaced in both the Sotraki and Buhimba sites. In addition, through UNICEF RRMP funds, NRC has provided transportation of displaced to the Buhimba site in an effort to decongest the Sotraki site. 
Plans are underway for an NFI distribution to be carried out through UNICEF RRMP partners NRC and Slidarités International.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

Upwards of 6,000 people fled their homes towards the city center, where they sought shelter in schools, churches, or with host families.

In response to the displacement the humanitarian community mobilized resources to create numerous temporary sites to cater to the displaced. UNICEF coordinated with partners Norwegian  Refugee Council (NRC) and Norwegian Church Aid (NCA) to provide shelter and Water, Sanitation and Hygiene as well as logistical support to the management of the sites. 

With more than 1,700 families staying at the Sotraki site (as of 04 June, 2013) UNICEF partner NCA responded within one week of the displacement to construct 16 latrines,12 showers, and instal a 30m3 water bladder which provides a constant flow to 12 taps in the site. In addition, NCA hygiene teams have organized and supervised the regular cleaning of the latrines, as well as spreading general hygiene messages.
NRC has contributed to the establishment of numerous tents in which to hose the displaced in both the Sotraki and Buhimba sites. In addition, through UNICEF RRMP funds, NRC has provided transportation of displaced to the Buhimba site in an effort to decongest the Sotraki site. 
Plans are underway for an NFI distribution to be carried out through UNICEF RRMP partners NRC and Slidarités International.";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:1370001822;s:9:"copyright";s:24:"©UNICEF DRC/2013/Morton";s:12:"focal_length";s:2:"50";s:3:"iso";s:3:"320";s:13:"shutter_speed";s:5:"0.008";s:5:"title";s:1686:"Sotraki Temporary Site, Goma? 8th CEPAC, a local NGO operating in Goma distributes BP-5 buscuits and Plumpy nut to malnourished children living in the Sotraki site? Following months of relative peace after the takeover of Goma by the M23 rebels in November, 2012, fighting once again broke out on the edge of Goma between the M23 and the Congolese Army (FARDC) in May, 2013. Upwards of 6,000 people fled their homes towards the city center, where they sought shelter in schools, churches, or with host families.

In response to the displacement the humanitarian community mobilized resources to create numerous temporary sites to cater to the displaced. UNICEF coordinated with partners Norwegian  Refugee Council (NRC) and Norwegian Church Aid (NCA) to provide shelter and Water, Sanitation and Hygiene as well as logistical support to the management of the sites. 

With more than 1,700 families staying at the Sotraki site (as of 04 June, 2013) UNICEF partner NCA responded within one week of the displacement to construct 16 latrines,12 showers, and instal a 30m3 water bladder which provides a constant flow to 12 taps in the site. In addition, NCA hygiene teams have organized and supervised the regular cleaning of the latrines, as well as spreading general hygiene messages.
NRC has contributed to the establishment of numerous tents in which to hose the displaced in both the Sotraki and Buhimba sites. In addition, through UNICEF RRMP funds, NRC has provided transportation of displaced to the Buhimba site in an effort to decongest the Sotraki site. 
Plans are underway for an NFI distribution to be carried out through UNICEF RRMP partners NRC and Slidarités International.";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

		<title>Boutons la polio hors de la RDC</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/unis-pour-bouter-la-polio-hors-de-la-rdc/boutons-la-polio-hors-de-la-rdc/</link>

	<item>
		<title>On August 16, 2013 UNICEF and Merlin, with the support of ECHO and UNHASS delivered 3.5 tons of medical/nutritional supplies to Nobili, North Kivu, DRC, as part of the OCHA/UNICEF led RRMP program. Following attacks on Kamongo by the ADF-Nalu rebels in July, more than 66,000 people were displaced from their homes in to surrounding villages in DRC and neighboring Uganda. RRMP assessments in late July revealed a 550% increase in child mortality and nearly 50% prevelance of diarrhea in children under 5. With many displaced settling in Nobili, approximately 9 km from Kamongo, the population more than tripled from 8,500 residents to 30,500. The hosiptal and health centers were looted during the attacks, leaving little resources to combat disease and malnutrition. Immediately following the distribution of supplies Merlin opened mobile health clinics in the area and began support to the hospital and area health centers, and together with UNICEF, the Ministry of Health and Lutheran World Federation (LWF) began a five-day measles vaccination campaign targeting more than 45,000 displaced and host-community children.</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/echo-renouvelle-son-soutien-a-la-reponse-rapide-aux-mouvements-de-population-dunicefocha-2/on-august-16-2013-unicef-and-merlin-with-the-support-of-echo-and-unhass-delivered-3-5-tons-of-medicalnutritional-supplies-to-nobili-north-kivu-drc-as-part-of-the-ochaunicef-led-rrmp-program-fo-3/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 17 Jan 2014 08:04:35 +0000</pubDate>

	<item>
		<title>The ECHO-funded UNHAS helicopter departs Kasika, Mwenga Territory.__The IASC Emergency Directors Group visit humanitarian activities in Mwenga, Territory, South Kivu, Democratic Republic of the Congo on Thursday, October 24, 2013.With numerous armed confrontations continuing in eastern DRC, more than 2.7 million are currently displaced. The visit of Emergency Directors, including OCHA Operations Director John Ging and UNICEF Director of Emergency Programs Ted Chaiban, among others, is meant to help create a shared understanding of challenges within the various humanitarian agencies present, as well as to help identify solutions to operational gaps. Traveling by ECHO-funded helicopter to Kasika, Mwenga, the Directors delegation visited an ECHO-funded Food Fair implemented by AVSI, a FAO-funded food security project, a health center supported by UNICEF carrying out support to malnourished children, as well as a food distribution funded by WFP and implemented by World Vision.</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/echo-renouvelle-son-soutien-a-la-reponse-rapide-aux-mouvements-de-population-dunicefocha/the-echo-funded-unhas-helicopter-departs-kasika-mwenga-territory-__the-iasc-emergency-directors-group-visit-humanitarian-activities-in-mwenga-territory-south-kivu-democratic-republic-of-the-co/</link>

__

The IASC Emergency Directors Group visit humanitarian activities in Mwenga, Territory, South Kivu, Democratic Republic of the Congo on Thursday, October 24, 2013.

With numerous armed confrontations continuing in eastern DRC, more than 2.7 million are currently displaced. The visit of Emergency Directors, including OCHA Operations Director John Ging and UNICEF Director of Emergency Programs Ted Chaiban, among others, is meant to help create a shared understanding of challenges within the various humanitarian agencies present, as well as to help identify solutions to operational gaps. 

Traveling by ECHO-funded helicopter to Kasika, Mwenga, the Directors delegation visited an ECHO-funded Food Fair implemented by AVSI, a FAO-funded food security project, a health center supported by UNICEF carrying out support to malnourished children, as well as a food distribution funded by WFP and implemented by World Vision.";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

		<title>UNICEF DRC 2013 Pudlowski Day of the Girl</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/journee-internationale-de-la-fille-importance-de-linnovation-pour-leducation/unicef-drc-2013-pudlowski-day-of-the-girl/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 17 Jan 2014 08:15:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Justine</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/UNICEF-DRC-2013-Pudlowski-Day-of-the-Girl.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>3884</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-01-17 08:15:25</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-01-17 08:15:25</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_metadata</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:5:{s:5:"width";i:623;s:6:"height";i:415;s:4:"file";s:53:"2013/10/UNICEF-DRC-2013-Pudlowski-Day-of-the-Girl.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:2:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:53:"UNICEF-DRC-2013-Pudlowski-Day-of-the-Girl-150x150.jpg";s:5:"width";i:150;s:6:"height";i:150;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}s:6:"medium";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:53:"UNICEF-DRC-2013-Pudlowski-Day-of-the-Girl-300x199.jpg";s:5:"width";i:300;s:6:"height";i:199;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:0;s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:0:"";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>UNICEF assists internally displaced persons with disabilitiesGoma, Democratic Republic of the Congo, 25 May 2013 - ?The wheelchair Meshak has received is very important as it?s very difficult for him to walk,? says Aline Vumilia, 22, as Meshak Batundi sits in a wheelchair for the first time and starts learning how to pedal.  ?He?s also received an adapted toilet because his access to public latrines is difficult too,? Vumilia adds. 8-year old Meshak walks on his knees because he contracted a disease that maimed his two feet and his right hand.  The young boy lives with his aunt Aline at Lac Vert Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) site near North Kivu?s capital Goma.  He was separated from his mother when armed conflict reached his village of Kitchanga last December. Restoring dignityThere are hundreds of people with disabilities amongst the thousands of displaced people who have settled around Goma, having fled from armed conflict in North Kivu, eastern DRC.  Basic services available at the IDP site pose accessibility problems to people with disabilities.  So, additional measures are required to make sure that these people have equal access to facilities and are able to live with dignity. Through the Rapid Response to Population Movements (RRMP) mechanism, UNICEF?s partner, Handicap International, distributes items such as crutches, walking canes, wheelchairs and adapted toilets. ?Now that they move on wheelchairs, these people who used to walk on all fours can get together with people more easily,? underlines Odette Katungo, a Handicap International physiotherapist. ?Their dignity is restored,? she adds.RRMP assisted over 1.5 million conflict-affected people in 2012The RRMP delivers an integrated assistance to acutely vulnerable populations affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters?including host families?while there are sites of displaced persons in some provinces, like Nord Kivu where Meshak and his aunt live, over 80% of IDPs in the D.R.Congo do not live in sites or camps, but with host families.  In partnership with OCHA and through seven stand-by INGO partners in Province Orientale, Katanga, North and South Kivu provinces, RRMP assisted over 1.5 million emergency-affected people in 2012 with access to water, hygiene and sanitation, essential household items, education and health services.The UNICEF/Handicap International RRMP project targets 300 displaced persons with disabilities living at Lac Vert and Bulengo, two IDP sites on the outskirts of Goma.  ?Among the displaced people here, there are persons living with disabilities who find it difficult to move or use the latrines,? Katungo explains.  ?That?s why Handicap International decided to provide them with different types of items to assist with mobility and walking,? she adds.  Displaced people living with disabilities are among the most vulnerable. UNICEF and its partners aim at reducing such vulnerability and improve their living conditions on the IDP sites or with host families until peace and security allow for their return to their villages of origin.[END]</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/?attachment_id=3887</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 17 Jan 2014 08:41:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/©UNICEF-RDC-Brett-Morton_130415111207.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[UNICEF assists internally displaced persons with disabilities
Goma, Democratic Republic of the Congo, 25 May 2013 - “The wheelchair Meshak has received is very important as it’s very difficult for him to walk,” says Aline Vumilia, 22, as Meshak Batundi sits in a wheelchair for the first time and starts learning how to pedal.  “He’s also received an adapted toilet because his access to public latrines is difficult too,” Vumilia adds. 

8-year old Meshak walks on his knees because he contracted a disease that maimed his two feet and his right hand.  The young boy lives with his aunt Aline at Lac Vert Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) site near North Kivu’s capital Goma.  He was separated from his mother when armed conflict reached his village of Kitchanga last December. 

Restoring dignity
There are hundreds of people with disabilities amongst the thousands of displaced people who have settled around Goma, having fled from armed conflict in North Kivu, eastern DRC.  Basic services available at the IDP site pose accessibility problems to people with disabilities.  So, additional measures are required to make sure that these people have equal access to facilities and are able to live with dignity. 
Through the Rapid Response to Population Movements (RRMP) mechanism, UNICEF’s partner, Handicap International, distributes items such as crutches, walking canes, wheelchairs and adapted toilets. “Now that they move on wheelchairs, these people who used to walk on all fours can get together with people more easily,” underlines Odette Katungo, a Handicap International physiotherapist. “Their dignity is restored,” she adds.
RRMP assisted over 1.5 million conflict-affected people in 2012
The RRMP delivers an integrated assistance to acutely vulnerable populations affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters—including host families—while there are sites of displaced persons in some provinces, like Nord Kivu where Meshak and his aunt live, over 80% of IDPs in the D.R.Congo do not live in sites or camps, but with host families.  In partnership with OCHA and through seven stand-by INGO partners in Province Orientale, Katanga, North and South Kivu provinces, RRMP assisted over 1.5 million emergency-affected people in 2012 with access to water, hygiene and sanitation, essential household items, education and health services.
The UNICEF/Handicap International RRMP project targets 300 displaced persons with disabilities living at Lac Vert and Bulengo, two IDP sites on the outskirts of Goma.  “Among the displaced people here, there are persons living with disabilities who find it difficult to move or use the latrines,” Katungo explains.  “That’s why Handicap International decided to provide them with different types of items to assist with mobility and walking,” she adds.  Displaced people living with disabilities are among the most vulnerable. UNICEF and its partners aim at reducing such vulnerability and improve their living conditions on the IDP sites or with host families until peace and security allow for their return to their villages of origin.
[END]]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>unicef-assists-internally-displaced-persons-with-disabilitiesgoma-democratic-republic-of-the-congo-25-may-2013-the-wheelchair-meshak-has-received-is-very-important-as-its-very-difficult-for-him</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>3886</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>attachment</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:attachment_url>http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/©UNICEF-RDC-Brett-Morton_130415111207.jpg</wp:attachment_url>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attached_file</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2014/01/©UNICEF-RDC-Brett-Morton_130415111207.jpg]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_metadata</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:5:{s:5:"width";i:624;s:6:"height";i:416;s:4:"file";s:50:"2014/01/©UNICEF-RDC-Brett-Morton_130415111207.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:2:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:50:"©UNICEF-RDC-Brett-Morton_130415111207-150x150.jpg";s:5:"width";i:150;s:6:"height";i:150;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}s:6:"medium";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:50:"©UNICEF-RDC-Brett-Morton_130415111207-300x200.jpg";s:5:"width";i:300;s:6:"height";i:200;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:12:"Brett Morton";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:3142:"UNICEF assists internally displaced persons with disabilities
Goma, Democratic Republic of the Congo, 25 May 2013 - “The wheelchair Meshak has received is very important as it’s very difficult for him to walk,” says Aline Vumilia, 22, as Meshak Batundi sits in a wheelchair for the first time and starts learning how to pedal.  “He’s also received an adapted toilet because his access to public latrines is difficult too,” Vumilia adds. 

8-year old Meshak walks on his knees because he contracted a disease that maimed his two feet and his right hand.  The young boy lives with his aunt Aline at Lac Vert Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) site near North Kivu’s capital Goma.  He was separated from his mother when armed conflict reached his village of Kitchanga last December. 

Restoring dignity
There are hundreds of people with disabilities amongst the thousands of displaced people who have settled around Goma, having fled from armed conflict in North Kivu, eastern DRC.  Basic services available at the IDP site pose accessibility problems to people with disabilities.  So, additional measures are required to make sure that these people have equal access to facilities and are able to live with dignity. 
Through the Rapid Response to Population Movements (RRMP) mechanism, UNICEF’s partner, Handicap International, distributes items such as crutches, walking canes, wheelchairs and adapted toilets. “Now that they move on wheelchairs, these people who used to walk on all fours can get together with people more easily,” underlines Odette Katungo, a Handicap International physiotherapist. “Their dignity is restored,” she adds.
RRMP assisted over 1.5 million conflict-affected people in 2012
The RRMP delivers an integrated assistance to acutely vulnerable populations affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters—including host families—while there are sites of displaced persons in some provinces, like Nord Kivu where Meshak and his aunt live, over 80% of IDPs in the D.R.Congo do not live in sites or camps, but with host families.  In partnership with OCHA and through seven stand-by INGO partners in Province Orientale, Katanga, North and South Kivu provinces, RRMP assisted over 1.5 million emergency-affected people in 2012 with access to water, hygiene and sanitation, essential household items, education and health services.
The UNICEF/Handicap International RRMP project targets 300 displaced persons with disabilities living at Lac Vert and Bulengo, two IDP sites on the outskirts of Goma.  “Among the displaced people here, there are persons living with disabilities who find it difficult to move or use the latrines,” Katungo explains.  “That’s why Handicap International decided to provide them with different types of items to assist with mobility and walking,” she adds.  Displaced people living with disabilities are among the most vulnerable. UNICEF and its partners aim at reducing such vulnerability and improve their living conditions on the IDP sites or with host families until peace and security allow for their return to their villages of origin.
[END]";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:1366024327;s:9:"copyright";s:29:"© UNICEF RDC / 2013 / Morton";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:3104:"UNICEF assists internally displaced persons with disabilities
Goma, Democratic Republic of the Congo, 25 May 2013 - ?The wheelchair Meshak has received is very important as it?s very difficult for him to walk,? says Aline Vumilia, 22, as Meshak Batundi sits in a wheelchair for the first time and starts learning how to pedal.  ?He?s also received an adapted toilet because his access to public latrines is difficult too,? Vumilia adds. 

8-year old Meshak walks on his knees because he contracted a disease that maimed his two feet and his right hand.  The young boy lives with his aunt Aline at Lac Vert Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) site near North Kivu?s capital Goma.  He was separated from his mother when armed conflict reached his village of Kitchanga last December. 

Restoring dignity
There are hundreds of people with disabilities amongst the thousands of displaced people who have settled around Goma, having fled from armed conflict in North Kivu, eastern DRC.  Basic services available at the IDP site pose accessibility problems to people with disabilities.  So, additional measures are required to make sure that these people have equal access to facilities and are able to live with dignity. 
Through the Rapid Response to Population Movements (RRMP) mechanism, UNICEF?s partner, Handicap International, distributes items such as crutches, walking canes, wheelchairs and adapted toilets. ?Now that they move on wheelchairs, these people who used to walk on all fours can get together with people more easily,? underlines Odette Katungo, a Handicap International physiotherapist. ?Their dignity is restored,? she adds.
RRMP assisted over 1.5 million conflict-affected people in 2012
The RRMP delivers an integrated assistance to acutely vulnerable populations affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters?including host families?while there are sites of displaced persons in some provinces, like Nord Kivu where Meshak and his aunt live, over 80% of IDPs in the D.R.Congo do not live in sites or camps, but with host families.  In partnership with OCHA and through seven stand-by INGO partners in Province Orientale, Katanga, North and South Kivu provinces, RRMP assisted over 1.5 million emergency-affected people in 2012 with access to water, hygiene and sanitation, essential household items, education and health services.
The UNICEF/Handicap International RRMP project targets 300 displaced persons with disabilities living at Lac Vert and Bulengo, two IDP sites on the outskirts of Goma.  ?Among the displaced people here, there are persons living with disabilities who find it difficult to move or use the latrines,? Katungo explains.  ?That?s why Handicap International decided to provide them with different types of items to assist with mobility and walking,? she adds.  Displaced people living with disabilities are among the most vulnerable. UNICEF and its partners aim at reducing such vulnerability and improve their living conditions on the IDP sites or with host families until peace and security allow for their return to their villages of origin.
[END]";}}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Elena Locatelli :C&#039;est avec une grande joie que l&#039;UNICEF s&#039;associe ce jour à Goma à la remise officielle symbolique des matériels et équipements par le Ministre de la Santé Publique, au Gouverneur de la province du Nord Kivu.Pour la première fois, le Gouvernement de RDC s&#039;est engagé comme donateur direct avec l&#039;UNICEF à acheter, dans le cadre du Projet d?équipement des structures sanitaires (PESS), les équipements médicaux pour couvrir les besoins en matériels médico-sanitaires de 200 hôpitaux généraux de référence et 1000 centres de santé dans les 11 provinces du pays en trois phases d&#039;ici à mi-2015. A ce stade, dans le cadre des phases 1 et 2, les équipements pour 132 hôpitaux et 660 centres de santé ont été livrés ou sont en cours d&#039;achat, à travers la centrale d&#039;achat de l&#039;UNICEF à Copenhague.Le volume financier contribué par le gouvernement à travers l&#039;UNICEF dans le cadre des phases 1 et 2 s&#039;élève à 29.8 millions de dollars américains.La troisième phase, planifiée pour 2014, ciblera 68 Hôpitaux et 340 centres de sante additionnels et coutera 22 millions de dollars, que le gouvernement de RDC s&#039;est engagé à financer.L&#039;acheminement des équipements a représenté des défis, avec environ 140 containers de 40 pieds (67 mètres cubes) expédies par bateaux et partiellement par avions en RDC pour la première phase seule, et 420 containers attendus au total pour les trois phases. L&#039;UNICEF est responsable pour l&#039;ensemble de la chaine d&#039;approvisionnement depuis la commande, jusqu&#039;au transport maritime et aerien, a la réception et l&#039;entreposage, le conditionnement, l&#039;évaluation techniques des structures cibles, la distribution in-country, et la formation des bénéficiaires finaux pendant l&#039;installation dans les sites. Les matériels et équipements qui viennent d?être remis par le Ministère de la santé Publique vont renforcer le système de santé et aider à une meilleure prise en charge de la population.  L&#039;espoir de l&#039;UNICEF est que grâce à cette volonté politique nationale forte, tous les enfants et leurs mamans, même ceux des zones les plus reculées de RDC puissent avoir accès aux soins de qualité permettant de vaincre les principales causes de mortalité.   Ces efforts du gouvernement congolais sont une contribution significative à la « promesse renouvelée » pour l&#039;avancement du pays vers les OMD 4 et 5, qui vise à sauver 430 000 vies d?enfants de 0 à 5 ans et 7 900 vies de mères d?ici fin 2015.Nous saisissons cette occasion pour féliciter le gouvernement et l&#039;encourager à poursuivre ses efforts en faveur de la santé de la mère et de l?enfant dans le cadre de l?approche « Naître, grandir, progresser ».</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/pres-de-800-infrastructures-de-sante-equipees-pour-sauver-430-000-enfants-et-7-900-meres-en-rdc-dici-fin-2015/elena-locatelli-cest-avec-une-grande-joie-que-lunicef-sassocie-ce-jour-a-goma-a-la-remise-officielle-symbolique-des-materiels-et-equipements-par-le-ministre-de-la-sante-publique-au-gouverneur-d/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 17 Jan 2014 10:09:24 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Justine</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/UNICEF-2013-Morton-Medical-Supply-Boxes-231113.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Elena Locatelli :

C'est avec une grande joie que l'UNICEF s'associe ce jour à Goma à la remise officielle symbolique des matériels et équipements par le Ministre de la Santé Publique, au Gouverneur de la province du Nord Kivu.

Pour la première fois, le Gouvernement de RDC s'est engagé comme donateur direct avec l'UNICEF à acheter, dans le cadre du Projet d’équipement des structures sanitaires (PESS), les équipements médicaux pour couvrir les besoins en matériels médico-sanitaires de 200 hôpitaux généraux de référence et 1000 centres de santé dans les 11 provinces du pays en trois phases d'ici à mi-2015. 

A ce stade, dans le cadre des phases 1 et 2, les équipements pour 132 hôpitaux et 660 centres de santé ont été livrés ou sont en cours d'achat, à travers la centrale d'achat de l'UNICEF à Copenhague.

Le volume financier contribué par le gouvernement à travers l'UNICEF dans le cadre des phases 1 et 2 s'élève à 29.8 millions de dollars américains.

La troisième phase, planifiée pour 2014, ciblera 68 Hôpitaux et 340 centres de sante additionnels et coutera 22 millions de dollars, que le gouvernement de RDC s'est engagé à financer.

L'acheminement des équipements a représenté des défis, avec environ 140 containers de 40 pieds (67 mètres cubes) expédies par bateaux et partiellement par avions en RDC pour la première phase seule, et 420 containers attendus au total pour les trois phases. L'UNICEF est responsable pour l'ensemble de la chaine d'approvisionnement depuis la commande, jusqu'au transport maritime et aerien, a la réception et l'entreposage, le conditionnement, l'évaluation techniques des structures cibles, la distribution in-country, et la formation des bénéficiaires finaux pendant l'installation dans les sites. 

Les matériels et équipements qui viennent d’être remis par le Ministère de la santé Publique vont renforcer le système de santé et aider à une meilleure prise en charge de la population.  

L'espoir de l'UNICEF est que grâce à cette volonté politique nationale forte, tous les enfants et leurs mamans, même ceux des zones les plus reculées de RDC puissent avoir accès aux soins de qualité permettant de vaincre les principales causes de mortalité.   

Ces efforts du gouvernement congolais sont une contribution significative à la « promesse renouvelée » pour l'avancement du pays vers les OMD 4 et 5, qui vise à sauver 430 000 vies d’enfants de 0 à 5 ans et 7 900 vies de mères d’ici fin 2015.

Nous saisissons cette occasion pour féliciter le gouvernement et l'encourager à poursuivre ses efforts en faveur de la santé de la mère et de l’enfant dans le cadre de l’approche « Naître, grandir, progresser ».]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>3</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/photo-de-la-semaine-17-janvier-2014/3-5/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 17 Jan 2014 10:18:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/32.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[Jonathan et Angélique]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>3899</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-01-17 10:18:33</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-01-17 10:18:33</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

	<item>
		<title>2</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/ces-enfants-sont-une-source-dinspiration-incroyable-pour-nous-tous/2-12/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 24 Jan 2014 13:36:35 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/28.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4124</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-01-24 13:36:35</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-01-24 13:36:35</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>2-12</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>4107</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
