	<item>
		<title>UNICEF assists internally displaced persons with disabilitiesGoma, Democratic Republic of the Congo, 25 May 2013 - ?The wheelchair Meshak has received is very important as it?s very difficult for him to walk,? says Aline Vumilia, 22, as Meshak Batundi sits in a wheelchair for the first time and starts learning how to pedal.  ?He?s also received an adapted toilet because his access to public latrines is difficult too,? Vumilia adds. 8-year old Meshak walks on his knees because he contracted a disease that maimed his two feet and his right hand.  The young boy lives with his aunt Aline at Lac Vert Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) site near North Kivu?s capital Goma.  He was separated from his mother when armed conflict reached his village of Kitchanga last December. Restoring dignityThere are hundreds of people with disabilities amongst the thousands of displaced people who have settled around Goma, having fled from armed conflict in North Kivu, eastern DRC.  Basic services available at the IDP site pose accessibility problems to people with disabilities.  So, additional measures are required to make sure that these people have equal access to facilities and are able to live with dignity. Through the Rapid Response to Population Movements (RRMP) mechanism, UNICEF?s partner, Handicap International, distributes items such as crutches, walking canes, wheelchairs and adapted toilets. ?Now that they move on wheelchairs, these people who used to walk on all fours can get together with people more easily,? underlines Odette Katungo, a Handicap International physiotherapist. ?Their dignity is restored,? she adds.RRMP assisted over 1.5 million conflict-affected people in 2012The RRMP delivers an integrated assistance to acutely vulnerable populations affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters?including host families?while there are sites of displaced persons in some provinces, like Nord Kivu where Meshak and his aunt live, over 80% of IDPs in the D.R.Congo do not live in sites or camps, but with host families.  In partnership with OCHA and through seven stand-by INGO partners in Province Orientale, Katanga, North and South Kivu provinces, RRMP assisted over 1.5 million emergency-affected people in 2012 with access to water, hygiene and sanitation, essential household items, education and health services.The UNICEF/Handicap International RRMP project targets 300 displaced persons with disabilities living at Lac Vert and Bulengo, two IDP sites on the outskirts of Goma.  ?Among the displaced people here, there are persons living with disabilities who find it difficult to move or use the latrines,? Katungo explains.  ?That?s why Handicap International decided to provide them with different types of items to assist with mobility and walking,? she adds.  Displaced people living with disabilities are among the most vulnerable. UNICEF and its partners aim at reducing such vulnerability and improve their living conditions on the IDP sites or with host families until peace and security allow for their return to their villages of origin.[END]</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/photo-de-la-semaine-31-janvier-2014/unicef-assists-internally-displaced-persons-with-disabilitiesgoma-democratic-republic-of-the-congo-25-may-2013-the-wheelchair-meshak-has-received-is-very-important-as-its-very-difficult-for-him-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 31 Jan 2014 09:23:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/©UNICEF-RDC-Brett-7.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[UNICEF assists internally displaced persons with disabilities
Goma, Democratic Republic of the Congo, 25 May 2013 - “The wheelchair Meshak has received is very important as it’s very difficult for him to walk,” says Aline Vumilia, 22, as Meshak Batundi sits in a wheelchair for the first time and starts learning how to pedal.  “He’s also received an adapted toilet because his access to public latrines is difficult too,” Vumilia adds. 

8-year old Meshak walks on his knees because he contracted a disease that maimed his two feet and his right hand.  The young boy lives with his aunt Aline at Lac Vert Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) site near North Kivu’s capital Goma.  He was separated from his mother when armed conflict reached his village of Kitchanga last December. 

Restoring dignity
There are hundreds of people with disabilities amongst the thousands of displaced people who have settled around Goma, having fled from armed conflict in North Kivu, eastern DRC.  Basic services available at the IDP site pose accessibility problems to people with disabilities.  So, additional measures are required to make sure that these people have equal access to facilities and are able to live with dignity. 
Through the Rapid Response to Population Movements (RRMP) mechanism, UNICEF’s partner, Handicap International, distributes items such as crutches, walking canes, wheelchairs and adapted toilets. “Now that they move on wheelchairs, these people who used to walk on all fours can get together with people more easily,” underlines Odette Katungo, a Handicap International physiotherapist. “Their dignity is restored,” she adds.
RRMP assisted over 1.5 million conflict-affected people in 2012
The RRMP delivers an integrated assistance to acutely vulnerable populations affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters—including host families—while there are sites of displaced persons in some provinces, like Nord Kivu where Meshak and his aunt live, over 80% of IDPs in the D.R.Congo do not live in sites or camps, but with host families.  In partnership with OCHA and through seven stand-by INGO partners in Province Orientale, Katanga, North and South Kivu provinces, RRMP assisted over 1.5 million emergency-affected people in 2012 with access to water, hygiene and sanitation, essential household items, education and health services.
The UNICEF/Handicap International RRMP project targets 300 displaced persons with disabilities living at Lac Vert and Bulengo, two IDP sites on the outskirts of Goma.  “Among the displaced people here, there are persons living with disabilities who find it difficult to move or use the latrines,” Katungo explains.  “That’s why Handicap International decided to provide them with different types of items to assist with mobility and walking,” she adds.  Displaced people living with disabilities are among the most vulnerable. UNICEF and its partners aim at reducing such vulnerability and improve their living conditions on the IDP sites or with host families until peace and security allow for their return to their villages of origin.
[END]]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>4375</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>attachment</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:attachment_url>http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/©UNICEF-RDC-Brett-7.jpg</wp:attachment_url>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attached_file</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2014/01/©UNICEF-RDC-Brett-7.jpg]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_metadata</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:5:{s:5:"width";i:633;s:6:"height";i:422;s:4:"file";s:32:"2014/01/©UNICEF-RDC-Brett-7.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:2:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:32:"©UNICEF-RDC-Brett-7-150x150.jpg";s:5:"width";i:150;s:6:"height";i:150;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}s:6:"medium";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:32:"©UNICEF-RDC-Brett-7-300x200.jpg";s:5:"width";i:300;s:6:"height";i:200;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:12:"Brett Morton";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:3142:"UNICEF assists internally displaced persons with disabilities
Goma, Democratic Republic of the Congo, 25 May 2013 - “The wheelchair Meshak has received is very important as it’s very difficult for him to walk,” says Aline Vumilia, 22, as Meshak Batundi sits in a wheelchair for the first time and starts learning how to pedal.  “He’s also received an adapted toilet because his access to public latrines is difficult too,” Vumilia adds. 

8-year old Meshak walks on his knees because he contracted a disease that maimed his two feet and his right hand.  The young boy lives with his aunt Aline at Lac Vert Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) site near North Kivu’s capital Goma.  He was separated from his mother when armed conflict reached his village of Kitchanga last December. 

Restoring dignity
There are hundreds of people with disabilities amongst the thousands of displaced people who have settled around Goma, having fled from armed conflict in North Kivu, eastern DRC.  Basic services available at the IDP site pose accessibility problems to people with disabilities.  So, additional measures are required to make sure that these people have equal access to facilities and are able to live with dignity. 
Through the Rapid Response to Population Movements (RRMP) mechanism, UNICEF’s partner, Handicap International, distributes items such as crutches, walking canes, wheelchairs and adapted toilets. “Now that they move on wheelchairs, these people who used to walk on all fours can get together with people more easily,” underlines Odette Katungo, a Handicap International physiotherapist. “Their dignity is restored,” she adds.
RRMP assisted over 1.5 million conflict-affected people in 2012
The RRMP delivers an integrated assistance to acutely vulnerable populations affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters—including host families—while there are sites of displaced persons in some provinces, like Nord Kivu where Meshak and his aunt live, over 80% of IDPs in the D.R.Congo do not live in sites or camps, but with host families.  In partnership with OCHA and through seven stand-by INGO partners in Province Orientale, Katanga, North and South Kivu provinces, RRMP assisted over 1.5 million emergency-affected people in 2012 with access to water, hygiene and sanitation, essential household items, education and health services.
The UNICEF/Handicap International RRMP project targets 300 displaced persons with disabilities living at Lac Vert and Bulengo, two IDP sites on the outskirts of Goma.  “Among the displaced people here, there are persons living with disabilities who find it difficult to move or use the latrines,” Katungo explains.  “That’s why Handicap International decided to provide them with different types of items to assist with mobility and walking,” she adds.  Displaced people living with disabilities are among the most vulnerable. UNICEF and its partners aim at reducing such vulnerability and improve their living conditions on the IDP sites or with host families until peace and security allow for their return to their villages of origin.
[END]";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:1366024327;s:9:"copyright";s:29:"© UNICEF RDC / 2013 / Morton";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:3104:"UNICEF assists internally displaced persons with disabilities
Goma, Democratic Republic of the Congo, 25 May 2013 - ?The wheelchair Meshak has received is very important as it?s very difficult for him to walk,? says Aline Vumilia, 22, as Meshak Batundi sits in a wheelchair for the first time and starts learning how to pedal.  ?He?s also received an adapted toilet because his access to public latrines is difficult too,? Vumilia adds. 

8-year old Meshak walks on his knees because he contracted a disease that maimed his two feet and his right hand.  The young boy lives with his aunt Aline at Lac Vert Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) site near North Kivu?s capital Goma.  He was separated from his mother when armed conflict reached his village of Kitchanga last December. 

Restoring dignity
There are hundreds of people with disabilities amongst the thousands of displaced people who have settled around Goma, having fled from armed conflict in North Kivu, eastern DRC.  Basic services available at the IDP site pose accessibility problems to people with disabilities.  So, additional measures are required to make sure that these people have equal access to facilities and are able to live with dignity. 
Through the Rapid Response to Population Movements (RRMP) mechanism, UNICEF?s partner, Handicap International, distributes items such as crutches, walking canes, wheelchairs and adapted toilets. ?Now that they move on wheelchairs, these people who used to walk on all fours can get together with people more easily,? underlines Odette Katungo, a Handicap International physiotherapist. ?Their dignity is restored,? she adds.
RRMP assisted over 1.5 million conflict-affected people in 2012
The RRMP delivers an integrated assistance to acutely vulnerable populations affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters?including host families?while there are sites of displaced persons in some provinces, like Nord Kivu where Meshak and his aunt live, over 80% of IDPs in the D.R.Congo do not live in sites or camps, but with host families.  In partnership with OCHA and through seven stand-by INGO partners in Province Orientale, Katanga, North and South Kivu provinces, RRMP assisted over 1.5 million emergency-affected people in 2012 with access to water, hygiene and sanitation, essential household items, education and health services.
The UNICEF/Handicap International RRMP project targets 300 displaced persons with disabilities living at Lac Vert and Bulengo, two IDP sites on the outskirts of Goma.  ?Among the displaced people here, there are persons living with disabilities who find it difficult to move or use the latrines,? Katungo explains.  ?That?s why Handicap International decided to provide them with different types of items to assist with mobility and walking,? she adds.  Displaced people living with disabilities are among the most vulnerable. UNICEF and its partners aim at reducing such vulnerability and improve their living conditions on the IDP sites or with host families until peace and security allow for their return to their villages of origin.
[END]";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>On August 16, 2013 UNICEF and Merlin, with the support of ECHO and UNHASS delivered 3.5 tons of medical/nutritional supplies to Nobili, North Kivu, DRC, as part of the OCHA/UNICEF led RRMP program. Following attacks on Kamongo by the ADF-Nalu rebels in July, more than 66,000 people were displaced from their homes in to surrounding villages in DRC and neighboring Uganda. RRMP assessments in late July revealed a 550% increase in child mortality and nearly 50% prevelance of diarrhea in children under 5. With many displaced settling in Nobili, approximately 9 km from Kamongo, the population more than tripled from 8,500 residents to 30,500. The hosiptal and health centers were looted during the attacks, leaving little resources to combat disease and malnutrition. Immediately following the distribution of supplies Merlin opened mobile health clinics in the area and began support to the hospital and area health centers, and together with UNICEF, the Ministry of Health and Lutheran World Federation (LWF) began a five-day measles vaccination campaign targeting more than 45,000 displaced and host-community children.</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/des-soins-de-sante-gratuits-pour-les-deplaces/on-august-16-2013-unicef-and-merlin-with-the-support-of-echo-and-unhass-delivered-3-5-tons-of-medicalnutritional-supplies-to-nobili-north-kivu-drc-as-part-of-the-ochaunicef-led-rrmp-program-fo-4/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 03 Feb 2014 11:16:20 +0000</pubDate>

Following attacks on Kamongo by the ADF-Nalu rebels in July, more than 66,000 people were displaced from their homes in to surrounding villages in DRC and neighboring Uganda. Following attacks on Kamongo by the ADF-Nalu rebels in July, more than 66,000 people were displaced from their homes in to surrounding villages in DRC and neighboring Uganda. RRMP assessments in late July revealed a 550% increase in child mortality and nearly 50% prevelance of diarrhea in children under 5. With many displaced settling in Nobili, approximately 9 km from Kamongo, the population more than tripled from 8,500 residents to 30,500. The hosiptal and health centers were looted during the attacks, leaving little resources to combat disease and malnutrition. Immediately following the distribution of supplies Merlin opened mobile health clinics in the area and began support to the hospital and area health centers, and together with UNICEF, the Ministry of Health and Lutheran World Federation (LWF) began a five-day measles vaccination campaign targeting more than 45,000 displaced and host-community children.]]></content:encoded>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[On August 16, 2013 UNICEF and Merlin, with the support of ECHO and UNHASS delivered 3.5 tons of medical/nutritional supplies to Nobili, North Kivu, DRC, as part of the OCHA/UNICEF led RRMP program. Following attacks on Kamongo by the ADF-Nalu rebels in July, more than 66,000 people were displaced from their homes in to surrounding villages in DRC and neighboring Uganda. RRMP assessments in late July revealed a 550% increase in child mortality and nearly 50% prevelance of diarrhea in children under 5. With many displaced settling in Nobili, approximately 9 km from Kamongo, the population more than tripled from 8,500 residents to 30,500. The hosiptal and health centers were looted during the attacks, leaving little resources to combat disease and malnutrition. Immediately following the distribution of supplies Merlin opened mobile health clinics in the area and began support to the hospital and area health centers, and together with UNICEF, the Ministry of Health and Lutheran World Federation (LWF) began a five-day measles vaccination campaign targeting more than 45,000 displaced and host-community children.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>UNICEF DRC Brett Morton 2013 Nobili</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/des-soins-de-sante-gratuits-pour-les-deplaces/unicef-drc-brett-morton-2013-nobili/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 03 Feb 2014 11:31:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Justine</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/UNICEF-DRC-Brett-Morton-2013-Nobili.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[On August 16, 2013 UNICEF and Merlin, with the support of ECHO and UNHASS delivered 3.5 tons of medical/nutritional supplies to Nobili, North Kivu, DRC, as part of the OCHA/UNICEF led RRMP program. Following attacks on Kamongo by the ADF-Nalu rebels in July, more than 66,000 people were displaced from their homes in to surrounding villages in DRC and neighboring Uganda. RRMP assessments in late July revealed a 550% increase in child mortality and nearly 50% prevelance of diarrhea in children under 5. With many displaced settling in Nobili, approximately 9 km from Kamongo, the population more than tripled from 8,500 residents to 30,500. The hosiptal and health centers were looted during the attacks, leaving little resources to combat disease and malnutrition. Immediately following the distribution of supplies Merlin opened mobile health clinics in the area and began support to the hospital and area health centers, and together with UNICEF, the Ministry of Health and Lutheran World Federation (LWF) began a five-day measles vaccination campaign targeting more than 45,000 displaced and host-community children.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

Following attacks on Kamongo by the ADF-Nalu rebels in July, more than 66,000 people were displaced from their homes in to surrounding villages in DRC and neighboring Uganda. RRMP assessments in late July revealed a 550% increase in child mortality and nearly 50% prevelance of diarrhea in children under 5. With many displaced settling in Nobili, approximately 9 km from Kamongo, the population more than tripled from 8,500 residents to 30,500. The hosiptal and health centers were looted during the attacks, leaving little resources to combat disease and malnutrition. Immediately following the distribution of supplies Merlin opened mobile health clinics in the area and began support to the hospital and area health centers, and together with UNICEF, the Ministry of Health and Lutheran World Federation (LWF) began a five-day measles vaccination campaign targeting more than 45,000 displaced and host-community children.";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:1376651339;s:9:"copyright";s:25:"© UNICEF RDC/2013/Morton";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:0:"";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

		<title>130816102841</title>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[On August 16, 2013 UNICEF and Merlin, with the support of ECHO and UNHASS delivered 3.5 tons of medical/nutritional supplies to Nobili, North Kivu, DRC, as part of the OCHA/UNICEF led RRMP program. Following attacks on Kamongo by the ADF-Nalu rebels in July, more than 66,000 people were displaced from their homes in to surrounding villages in DRC and neighboring Uganda. RRMP assessments in late July revealed a 550% increase in child mortality and nearly 50% prevelance of diarrhea in children under 5. With many displaced settling in Nobili, approximately 9 km from Kamongo, the population more than tripled from 8,500 residents to 30,500. The hosiptal and health centers were looted during the attacks, leaving little resources to combat disease and malnutrition. Immediately following the distribution of supplies Merlin opened mobile health clinics in the area and began support to the hospital and area health centers, and together with UNICEF, the Ministry of Health and Lutheran World Federation (LWF) began a five-day measles vaccination campaign targeting more than 45,000 displaced and host-community children.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>UNICEF DRC 2013 Morton Road to Nobili</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/des-soins-de-sante-gratuits-pour-les-deplaces/unicef-drc-2013-morton-road-to-nobili/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 03 Feb 2014 11:33:18 +0000</pubDate>

		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4421</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-02-03 11:33:18</wp:post_date>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>unicef-drc-2013-morton-road-to-nobili</wp:post_name>

	<item>
		<title>UNICEF DRC 2013 Morton Smile of the Week 06Feb2014</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/sourire-de-la-semaine-6-fevrier-2014/unicef-drc-2013-morton-smile-of-the-week-06feb2014/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 07 Feb 2014 10:50:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Justine</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/UNICEF-DRC-2013-Morton-Smile-of-the-Week-06Feb2014.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[March 15, 2013
Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRC
UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.

Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki  and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program – co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando. 

From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families. 

Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners’ relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations. 

Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This “Fair Approach” represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4484</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>unicef-drc-2013-morton-smile-of-the-week-06feb2014</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>4483</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>attachment</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:attachment_url>http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/UNICEF-DRC-2013-Morton-Smile-of-the-Week-06Feb2014.jpg</wp:attachment_url>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_metadata</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:5:{s:5:"width";i:622;s:6:"height";i:415;s:4:"file";s:62:"2014/02/UNICEF-DRC-2013-Morton-Smile-of-the-Week-06Feb2014.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:2:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:62:"UNICEF-DRC-2013-Morton-Smile-of-the-Week-06Feb2014-150x150.jpg";s:5:"width";i:150;s:6:"height";i:150;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}s:6:"medium";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:62:"UNICEF-DRC-2013-Morton-Smile-of-the-Week-06Feb2014-300x200.jpg";s:5:"width";i:300;s:6:"height";i:200;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:12:"Brett Morton";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:2068:"March 15, 2013

UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.

Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki  and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program – co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando. 

From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families. 

Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners’ relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations. 

Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This “Fair Approach” represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:1368630998;s:9:"copyright";s:29:"© UNICEF RDC / 2013 / Morton";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:0:"";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>NYHQ2012-0883</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/ensemble-contre-lutilisation-denfants-soldats/nyhq2012-0883/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 12 Feb 2014 16:56:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Justine</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/UNICEF-NYHQ2012-0883-BRIAN-SOKOL.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Zainab [NAME CHANGED], 16, stands in a UNICEF-assisted transit centre for recently released former child soldiers, in the town of Ndele, capital of the northern Bamingui-Bangoran Prefecture. Wanting to avenge the death of her fiancé, Zainab joined an armed group but, once recruited, was frequently sexually abused by male soldiers. She is now recovering at the centre, where she receives basic business training to pursue her dream of owning a restaurant. All she talks about is going back home, said a child protection specialist who works at the centre.

From 18 to 23 August 2012 in the Central African Republic (CAR), UNICEF Advocate for Children Affected by War Ishmael Beah met with children recently released from participation in armed groups, in the northern town of NDele, near the border with Chad. The children are presently staying at a UNICEF-assisted transit centre run by the Danish Refugee Council. Mr. Beah also witnessed the release of 10 children from the armed group Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace (CPJP), at a nearby military camp. Mr. Beah was himself forcibly recruited into armed forces during the civil war in his country, Sierra Leone. He was released from these forces in 1996 with assistance from UNICEF  a story he recounts in his 2007 bestselling book, A Long Way Gone: Memoirs of a Boy Soldier. Mr. Beah shared some of these experiences with the children in NDele and read them portions of his book. When you are conditioned to function in war, it takes time to know that something else is possible. I went through that myself, he told the children. He later remarked, These children have been through so much, but their release marks just the beginning. Many of the children have little to return to  [and] urgently require special care over the long term. The transit centre aims to help the children overcome some of the effects of the abuse, exploitation and violence they have been subjected to and participated in. It provides counselling support, basic education, sport, cultural activities and vocational skills training for 45 children aged 1018 years. Three of the children presently at the centre are girls. Amid proliferating conflicts in the Central African Republic  one of the worlds poorest countries  numerous national and foreign armed groups use children to work as guards, combatants, domestic servants and sex slaves, amongst other roles. In Bangui, the capital, Mr. Beah also met with government and other officials to press for additional support to ensure an end to the forcible recruitment of children into armed groups. Worldwide, thousands of children continue to be deprived of their most basic rights through association with armed forces and groups. UNICEF continues to advocate for their release and supports ongoing rehabilitation and reintegration efforts that, since 1998, have assisted more than 100,000 children to integrate back into their communities.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4532</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-02-12 16:56:09</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-02-12 16:56:09</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>nyhq2012-0883</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>4531</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attached_file</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2014/02/UNICEF-NYHQ2012-0883-BRIAN-SOKOL-e1392224249911.jpg]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_metadata</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:5:{s:5:"width";i:622;s:6:"height";i:415;s:4:"file";s:59:"2014/02/UNICEF-NYHQ2012-0883-BRIAN-SOKOL-e1392224249911.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:3:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:44:"UNICEF-NYHQ2012-0883-BRIAN-SOKOL-150x150.jpg";s:5:"width";i:150;s:6:"height";i:150;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}s:6:"medium";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:44:"UNICEF-NYHQ2012-0883-BRIAN-SOKOL-300x200.jpg";s:5:"width";i:300;s:6:"height";i:200;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}s:5:"large";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:45:"UNICEF-NYHQ2012-0883-BRIAN-SOKOL-1024x682.jpg";s:5:"width";i:1024;s:6:"height";i:682;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:29:"© UNICEF/NYHQ2012-0883/Sokol";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:2973:"Zainab [NAME CHANGED], 16, stands in a UNICEF-assisted transit centre for recently released former child soldiers, in the town of Ndele, capital of the northern Bamingui-Bangoran Prefecture. Wanting to avenge the death of her fiancé, Zainab joined an armed group but, once recruited, was frequently sexually abused by male soldiers. She is now recovering at the centre, where she receives basic business training to pursue her dream of owning a restaurant. All she talks about is going back home, said a child protection specialist who works at the centre.

From 18 to 23 August 2012 in the Central African Republic (CAR), UNICEF Advocate for Children Affected by War Ishmael Beah met with children recently released from participation in armed groups, in the northern town of NDele, near the border with Chad. The children are presently staying at a UNICEF-assisted transit centre run by the Danish Refugee Council. Mr. Beah also witnessed the release of 10 children from the armed group Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace (CPJP), at a nearby military camp. Mr. Beah was himself forcibly recruited into armed forces during the civil war in his country, Sierra Leone. He was released from these forces in 1996 with assistance from UNICEF  a story he recounts in his 2007 bestselling book, A Long Way Gone: Memoirs of a Boy Soldier. Mr. Beah shared some of these experiences with the children in NDele and read them portions of his book. When you are conditioned to function in war, it takes time to know that something else is possible. I went through that myself, he told the children. He later remarked, These children have been through so much, but their release marks just the beginning. Many of the children have little to return to  [and] urgently require special care over the long term. The transit centre aims to help the children overcome some of the effects of the abuse, exploitation and violence they have been subjected to and participated in. It provides counselling support, basic education, sport, cultural activities and vocational skills training for 45 children aged 1018 years. Three of the children presently at the centre are girls. Amid proliferating conflicts in the Central African Republic  one of the worlds poorest countries  numerous national and foreign armed groups use children to work as guards, combatants, domestic servants and sex slaves, amongst other roles. In Bangui, the capital, Mr. Beah also met with government and other officials to press for additional support to ensure an end to the forcible recruitment of children into armed groups. Worldwide, thousands of children continue to be deprived of their most basic rights through association with armed forces and groups. UNICEF continues to advocate for their release and supports ongoing rehabilitation and reintegration efforts that, since 1998, have assisted more than 100,000 children to integrate back into their communities.";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:0;s:9:"copyright";s:871:"© Notice: UNICEF photographs are copyrighted and may not be reproduced in any medium without written permission from authorized UNICEF staff. Permission is available to UNICEF partners and bonafide national/international media for specified use relating to UNICEF-supported issues or programmes. Permissions are granted for one-time use in a context that accurately represents the real situation and identity of all human beings depicted. All reproductions MUST be credited, including, at a minimum, the copyright symbol - © - UNICEF and the last name of the photographer. Reproductions without credit are not authorized. Images may not be used in a commercial context; may not be archived by any non-UNICEF entity; and are not available for personal use. Thank you for supporting UNICEF.";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:13:"NYHQ2012-0883";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>NYHQ2005-0439</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/ensemble-contre-lutilisation-denfants-soldats/nyhq2005-0439-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 12 Feb 2014 16:56:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Justine</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/UNI41652.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Boys raise their hands to shield their faces and their identities as former child soldiers, at a UNICEF-supported Centre de Transit et Orientation (CTO), a shelter and reintegration centre for recently demobilized child soldiers, in the eastern town of Goma, capital of North Kivu Province. The CTO provides medical and psychosocial care, as well as family tracing and reunification services. Nationwide, over 33,000 child soldiers remain active.

In March 2005 in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), insecurity and massive population displacements continue to challenge relief efforts in the eastern part of the country. An upsurge in violence in the resource-rich Ituri region, including the killing in February of nine MONUC (United Nations Organization Mission in the DRC) peacekeepers, led to a temporary suspension in humanitarian aid to tens of thousands of displaced civilians. Over two-thirds of the displaced are children and women. As aid resumes, the number of displaced continues to grow: up to 88,000 are registered in camps but many more are assumed to be in need of shelter. Some 6 million people throughout the north-eastern region are affected by the ongoing conflict. Hundreds of thousands are victimized in atrocities committed with impunity. Recruitment of child soldiers by all military factions continues. Rape of girls and women is a widespread weapon of war, terrorizing the population and increasing HIV prevalence. This regional fighting is part of a seven-year conflict in which up to 5 million Congolese have died from starvation, disease and warfare. UNICEF is working with other relief groups to meet the basic needs of displaced children and women, as well as to support child soldier demobilization efforts and other health, water and sanitation, education and protection initiatives in the region.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Enfant Reporter réconcilie pygmées et bantous</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/comment-on-a-reconcilie-les-pygmees-et-les-bantous-dans-notre-ecole/enfant-reporter-reconcilie-pygmees-et-bantous/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 13 Feb 2014 14:05:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Justine</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Enfant-Reporter-réconcilie-pygmées-et-bantous.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4560</wp:post_id>

			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attached_file</wp:meta_key>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>(Right) Clemence [NAME CHANGED], 16, holds her mother?s hand while visiting her at her home, in Bria, capital of Haute-Kotto Prefecture. After four years in the Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace rebel group, she was released about two weeks ago with assistance from UNICEF. Though she currently stays in a UNICEF-supported transit centre for recently released former child soldiers, also in Bria, she visits her mother regularly. The centre provides shelter, psychosocial support, health care, education and vocational opportunities while working to reintegrate children with their families.In December 2012 in the Central African Republic, conflict continues to worsen living conditions in what is already one of the world?s poorest countries, with one of the highest rates of under-five child mortality. Vital infrastructure has been destroyed, severely constricting access to healthcare, education and other basic services. Additionally, numerous national and foreign armed groups continue to forcibly recruit children, using them as guards, combatants, domestic servants and sex slaves, among other roles. UNICEF supports transit centres that help children overcome some of the effects of the abuse, exploitation and violence to which they have been subjected and in which they have participated. The centres provide shelter, psychosocial support, health care, education and vocational opportunities while working to reintegrate children with their families. Worldwide, thousands of children remain deprived of their most basic rights through association with armed forces and groups. UNICEF continues to advocate for their release and supports ongoing rehabilitation efforts that, since 1998, have assisted more than 100,000 children to reintegrate with their communities.</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/lappel-des-enfants-reporters-du-katanga-contre-lutilisation-denfants-soldats/right-clemence-name-changed-16-holds-her-mothers-hand-while-visiting-her-at-her-home-in-bria-capital-of-haute-kotto-prefecture-after-four-years-in-the-convention-of-patriots-for-justice-and/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 13 Feb 2014 15:30:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/©-UNICEF-NYHQ2012-2308-JORDI-MATAS.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[(Right) Clemence [NAME CHANGED], 16, holds her mother’s hand while visiting her at her home, in Bria, capital of Haute-Kotto Prefecture. After four years in the Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace rebel group, she was released about two weeks ago with assistance from UNICEF. Though she currently stays in a UNICEF-supported transit centre for recently released former child soldiers, also in Bria, she visits her mother regularly. The centre provides shelter, psychosocial support, health care, education and vocational opportunities while working to reintegrate children with their families.

In December 2012 in the Central African Republic, conflict continues to worsen living conditions in what is already one of the world’s poorest countries, with one of the highest rates of under-five child mortality. Vital infrastructure has been destroyed, severely constricting access to healthcare, education and other basic services. Additionally, numerous national and foreign armed groups continue to forcibly recruit children, using them as guards, combatants, domestic servants and sex slaves, among other roles. UNICEF supports transit centres that help children overcome some of the effects of the abuse, exploitation and violence to which they have been subjected and in which they have participated. The centres provide shelter, psychosocial support, health care, education and vocational opportunities while working to reintegrate children with their families. Worldwide, thousands of children remain deprived of their most basic rights through association with armed forces and groups. UNICEF continues to advocate for their release and supports ongoing rehabilitation efforts that, since 1998, have assisted more than 100,000 children to reintegrate with their communities.]]></content:encoded>

		<title>ER singing on the Rights of the Child at Sango IDP site-2</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/comment-on-a-reconcilie-les-pygmees-et-les-bantous-dans-notre-ecole/er-singing-on-the-rights-of-the-child-at-sango-idp-site-2/</link>

	<item>
		<title>Clemence [NAME CHANGED], 16, rests her right hand atop her left on a wooden surface in a UNICEF-supported transit centre for recently released former child soldiers, in Bria, capital of Haute-Kotto Prefecture. After four years in the Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace rebel group, she was released about two weeks ago with assistance from UNICEF. Though she currently stays in the centre ? which provides shelter, psychosocial support, health care, education and vocational opportunities while working to reintegrate children with their families ? she regularly visits her mother.In December 2012 in the Central African Republic, conflict continues to worsen living conditions in what is already one of the world?s poorest countries, with one of the highest rates of under-five child mortality. Vital infrastructure has been destroyed, severely constricting access to healthcare, education and other basic services. Additionally, numerous national and foreign armed groups continue to forcibly recruit children, using them as guards, combatants, domestic servants and sex slaves, among other roles. UNICEF supports transit centres that help children overcome some of the effects of the abuse, exploitation and violence to which they have been subjected and in which they have participated. The centres provide shelter, psychosocial support, health care, education and vocational opportunities while working to reintegrate children with their families. Worldwide, thousands of children remain deprived of their most basic rights through association with armed forces and groups. UNICEF continues to advocate for their release and supports ongoing rehabilitation efforts that, since 1998, have assisted more than 100,000 children to reintegrate with their communities.</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/lappel-des-enfants-reporters-du-katanga-contre-lutilisation-denfants-soldats/clemence-name-changed-16-rests-her-right-hand-atop-her-left-on-a-wooden-surface-in-a-unicef-supported-transit-centre-for-recently-released-former-child-soldiers-in-bria-capital-of-haute-kotto-pr/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 13 Feb 2014 16:15:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/UNI142238.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Clemence [NAME CHANGED], 16, rests her right hand atop her left on a wooden surface in a UNICEF-supported transit centre for recently released former child soldiers, in Bria, capital of Haute-Kotto Prefecture. After four years in the Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace rebel group, she was released about two weeks ago with assistance from UNICEF. Though she currently stays in the centre – which provides shelter, psychosocial support, health care, education and vocational opportunities while working to reintegrate children with their families – she regularly visits her mother.

In December 2012 in the Central African Republic, conflict continues to worsen living conditions in what is already one of the world’s poorest countries, with one of the highest rates of under-five child mortality. Vital infrastructure has been destroyed, severely constricting access to healthcare, education and other basic services. Additionally, numerous national and foreign armed groups continue to forcibly recruit children, using them as guards, combatants, domestic servants and sex slaves, among other roles. UNICEF supports transit centres that help children overcome some of the effects of the abuse, exploitation and violence to which they have been subjected and in which they have participated. The centres provide shelter, psychosocial support, health care, education and vocational opportunities while working to reintegrate children with their families. Worldwide, thousands of children remain deprived of their most basic rights through association with armed forces and groups. UNICEF continues to advocate for their release and supports ongoing rehabilitation efforts that, since 1998, have assisted more than 100,000 children to reintegrate with their communities.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[Au cours des cinq dernières années, ce sont au total plus de 22.000 enfants qui ont été séparés des forces et groupes armés en République Démocratique du Congo.]]></excerpt:encoded>

After four years in the Convention of Patriots for Justice and Peace rebel group, she was released about two weeks ago with assistance from UNICEF. Though she currently stays in the centre ? which provides shelter, psychosocial support, health care, education and vocational opportunities while working to reintegrate children with their families ? she regularly visits her mother.

In December 2012 in the Central African Republic, conflict continues to worsen living conditions in what is already one of the world?s poorest countries, with one of the highest rates of under-five child mortality. Vital infrastructure has been destroyed, severely constricting access to healthcare, education and other basic services. Additionally, numerous national and foreign armed groups continue to forcibly recruit children, using them as guards, combatants, domestic servants and sex slaves, among other roles. UNICEF supports transit centres that help children overcome some of the effects of the abuse, exploitation and violence to which they have been subjected and in which they have participated. The centres provide shelter, psychosocial support, health care, education and vocational opportunities while working to reintegrate children with their families. Worldwide, thousands of children remain deprived of their most basic rights through association with armed forces and groups. UNICEF continues to advocate for their release and supports ongoing rehabilitation efforts that, since 1998, have assisted more than 100,000 children to reintegrate with their communities.";}}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>

		<title>UNICEF DRC Brett Morton 2014 Sitrep January 2014</title>

		<pubDate>Sun, 16 Feb 2014 11:27:43 +0000</pubDate>

	<item>
		<title>UNICEF DRC HUmanitarian Situation Report 1-31 January 2014</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/situation-humanitaire-janvier-2014/unicef-drc-humanitarian-situation-report-1-31-january-2014/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 16 Feb 2014 15:39:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Justine</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/UNICEF-DRC-HUmanitarian-Situation-Report-1-31-January-2014.pdf</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4641</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-02-16 15:39:42</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-02-16 15:39:42</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>unicef-drc-humanitarian-situation-report-1-31-january-2014</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>4625</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>attachment</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:attachment_url>http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/UNICEF-DRC-HUmanitarian-Situation-Report-1-31-January-2014.pdf</wp:attachment_url>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attached_file</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2014/02/UNICEF-DRC-HUmanitarian-Situation-Report-1-31-January-2014.pdf]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>UNICEF Deputy Executive Director Yoka Brandt, WFP Deputy Executive Director Ramiro Lopes da Silva and UNHCR Assistant High Commissioner for Operations Janet Lim visit Lagabo, an IDP site 30km outside Bunia, in the Ituri Territory of Province Orentale, Democratic Republic of Congo.Calling on the international community to sustain support to the country?s large-scale humanitarian crisis, the group visited UNICEF Response to Movements of Population (RRMP) Education and WASH activities, as well as a UNICEF supported health center and WFP Food Distribution.In August 2013, fighting between the national army (FARDC) and local militias lead to the displacement of more than 120,000 in the Irumu Territory; Lagabo grew in a matter of days from few hundred people to a village hosting approximately 23,000 Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs).  At Lapa Primary School, which grew from 11 to 1,395 students at the height of displacement, the UNICEF-OCHA led Rapid Response to Movements of Population (RRMP) program responded constructing 9 classrooms training teachers and providing school kits. In addition, two water sources were rehabilitated and support provided to the health center.Yoka Brandt: ?I was impressed by Lagabo?s commitment and determination, and will remember well the message echoed by numerous people throughout the day: ?There can be no development without peace.? This day was a chance to better understand the harsh realities of displacement as we search for ways in which to continue to improve our joint efforts.?</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/situation-humanitaire-janvier-2014/unicef-deputy-executive-director-yoka-brandt-wfp-deputy-executive-director-ramiro-lopes-da-silva-and-unhcr-assistant-high-commissioner-for-operations-janet-lim-visit-lagabo-an-idp-site-30km-outside/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 17 Feb 2014 07:24:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Justine</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/UNICEF-DRC-Brett-Morton-SITREP-Janvier-2014.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[UNICEF Deputy Executive Director Yoka Brandt, WFP Deputy Executive Director Ramiro Lopes da Silva and UNHCR Assistant High Commissioner for Operations Janet Lim visit Lagabo, an IDP site 30km outside Bunia, in the Ituri Territory of Province Orentale, Democratic Republic of Congo.

Calling on the international community to sustain support to the country’s large-scale humanitarian crisis, the group visited UNICEF Response to Movements of Population (RRMP) Education and WASH activities, as well as a UNICEF supported health center and WFP Food Distribution.

In August 2013, fighting between the national army (FARDC) and local militias lead to the displacement of more than 120,000 in the Irumu Territory; Lagabo grew in a matter of days from few hundred people to a village hosting approximately 23,000 Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs).  

At Lapa Primary School, which grew from 11 to 1,395 students at the height of displacement, the UNICEF-OCHA led Rapid Response to Movements of Population (RRMP) program responded constructing 9 classrooms training teachers and providing school kits. In addition, two water sources were rehabilitated and support provided to the health center.

Yoka Brandt: “I was impressed by Lagabo’s commitment and determination, and will remember well the message echoed by numerous people throughout the day: “There can be no development without peace.” This day was a chance to better understand the harsh realities of displacement as we search for ways in which to continue to improve our joint efforts.”]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4646</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>unicef-deputy-executive-director-yoka-brandt-wfp-deputy-executive-director-ramiro-lopes-da-silva-and-unhcr-assistant-high-commissioner-for-operations-janet-lim-visit-lagabo-an-idp-site-30km-outside</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>4625</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>attachment</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attached_file</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2014/02/UNICEF-DRC-Brett-Morton-SITREP-Janvier-2014.jpg]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_metadata</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:5:{s:5:"width";i:620;s:6:"height";i:413;s:4:"file";s:55:"2014/02/UNICEF-DRC-Brett-Morton-SITREP-Janvier-2014.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:2:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:55:"UNICEF-DRC-Brett-Morton-SITREP-Janvier-2014-150x150.jpg";s:5:"width";i:150;s:6:"height";i:150;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}s:6:"medium";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:55:"UNICEF-DRC-Brett-Morton-SITREP-Janvier-2014-300x199.jpg";s:5:"width";i:300;s:6:"height";i:199;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:12:"Brett Morton";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:1554:"UNICEF Deputy Executive Director Yoka Brandt, WFP Deputy Executive Director Ramiro Lopes da Silva and UNHCR Assistant High Commissioner for Operations Janet Lim visit Lagabo, an IDP site 30km outside Bunia, in the Ituri Territory of Province Orentale, Democratic Republic of Congo.

Calling on the international community to sustain support to the country’s large-scale humanitarian crisis, the group visited UNICEF Response to Movements of Population (RRMP) Education and WASH activities, as well as a UNICEF supported health center and WFP Food Distribution.

In August 2013, fighting between the national army (FARDC) and local militias lead to the displacement of more than 120,000 in the Irumu Territory; Lagabo grew in a matter of days from few hundred people to a village hosting approximately 23,000 Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs).  

At Lapa Primary School, which grew from 11 to 1,395 students at the height of displacement, the UNICEF-OCHA led Rapid Response to Movements of Population (RRMP) program responded constructing 9 classrooms training teachers and providing school kits. In addition, two water sources were rehabilitated and support provided to the health center.

Yoka Brandt: “I was impressed by Lagabo’s commitment and determination, and will remember well the message echoed by numerous people throughout the day: “There can be no development without peace.” This day was a chance to better understand the harsh realities of displacement as we search for ways in which to continue to improve our joint efforts.”";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:1390301779;s:9:"copyright";s:12:"Brett Morton";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:1542:"UNICEF Deputy Executive Director Yoka Brandt, WFP Deputy Executive Director Ramiro Lopes da Silva and UNHCR Assistant High Commissioner for Operations Janet Lim visit Lagabo, an IDP site 30km outside Bunia, in the Ituri Territory of Province Orentale, Democratic Republic of Congo.

Calling on the international community to sustain support to the country?s large-scale humanitarian crisis, the group visited UNICEF Response to Movements of Population (RRMP) Education and WASH activities, as well as a UNICEF supported health center and WFP Food Distribution.

In August 2013, fighting between the national army (FARDC) and local militias lead to the displacement of more than 120,000 in the Irumu Territory; Lagabo grew in a matter of days from few hundred people to a village hosting approximately 23,000 Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs).  

At Lapa Primary School, which grew from 11 to 1,395 students at the height of displacement, the UNICEF-OCHA led Rapid Response to Movements of Population (RRMP) program responded constructing 9 classrooms training teachers and providing school kits. In addition, two water sources were rehabilitated and support provided to the health center.

Yoka Brandt: ?I was impressed by Lagabo?s commitment and determination, and will remember well the message echoed by numerous people throughout the day: ?There can be no development without peace.? This day was a chance to better understand the harsh realities of displacement as we search for ways in which to continue to improve our joint efforts.?";}}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>

	<item>
		<title>SUN</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/la-malnutrition-un-reel-frein-au-developpement-national/sun/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 18 Feb 2014 09:22:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4683</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-02-18 09:22:56</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-02-18 09:22:56</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>sun</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>

			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attached_file</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2014/02/SUN.jpg]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>UNICEF DRC 2013 Brett Morton.</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/comment-repondre-aux-crises-humanitaires-en-rdc-en-2014/following-completion-of-her-shopping-a-mother-waits-for-her-friends-outside-the-nfi-fair-in-kionvu-mwenga-south-kivu-drc-carried-out-by-unicef-rrmp-partner-avsi-in-may-2013-since-late-2012-fig/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 20 Feb 2014 16:51:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Justine</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/A-great-smile_Brett-Morton.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Following completion of her shopping, a mother waits for her friends outside the NFI Fair in Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRC carried out by UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI in May, 2013.

Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki  and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program – co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando. 

From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families. 

Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners’ relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations. 

Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This “Fair Approach” represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4750</wp:post_id>

		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>

	<item>
		<title>May 16, 2013.UNICEF partner TPO operates two Child Friendly Spaces (CFS) in Mwenga Center, South Kivu, DRC, providing nearly 4,000 children aged 2-18 with a protected environment in which to gather, supervised by staff trained in child protection. Designed to support and encourage their freedom of expression, right to play, to learn, to be stimulated and to develop their capacities in a friendly and warm environment, Child Friendly Spaces also offer an opportunity to sensitize children on basic issues like hygiene and sanitation, as well as the importance of education.?UNICEF funds our project in Mwenga, which is designed to reinforce the capacity of the community to respond on behalf of their vulnerable children,? explains Rwaha Rwakenga, a Social Worker for TPO, a Uganda-based NGO. ?One day we?re not going to be here, but the community must carry on with serving and protecting their children. For this reason the community is involved not only in the CFS, but also in trainings and sensitizations to make sure everyone in the community is aware of the importance of this for their children.?</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/comment-repondre-aux-crises-humanitaires-en-rdc-en-2014/may-16-2013-unicef-partner-tpo-operates-two-child-friendly-spaces-cfs-in-mwenga-center-south-kivu-drc-providing-nearly-4000-children-aged-2-18-with-a-protected-environment-in-which-to-gather/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 20 Feb 2014 17:23:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Justine</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/UNICEF-DRC-2013-Morton-Mwenga-Center-South-Kivu.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[May 16, 2013.
UNICEF partner TPO operates two Child Friendly Spaces (CFS) in Mwenga Center, South Kivu, DRC, providing nearly 4,000 children aged 2-18 with a protected environment in which to gather, supervised by staff trained in child protection. Designed to support and encourage their freedom of expression, right to play, to learn, to be stimulated and to develop their capacities in a friendly and warm environment, Child Friendly Spaces also offer an opportunity to sensitize children on basic issues like hygiene and sanitation, as well as the importance of education.


“UNICEF funds our project in Mwenga, which is designed to reinforce the capacity of the community to respond on behalf of their vulnerable children,” explains Rwaha Rwakenga, a Social Worker for TPO, a Uganda-based NGO. “One day we’re not going to be here, but the community must carry on with serving and protecting their children. For this reason the community is involved not only in the CFS, but also in trainings and sensitizations to make sure everyone in the community is aware of the importance of this for their children.”]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4754</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-02-20 17:23:40</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-02-20 17:23:40</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>may-16-2013-unicef-partner-tpo-operates-two-child-friendly-spaces-cfs-in-mwenga-center-south-kivu-drc-providing-nearly-4000-children-aged-2-18-with-a-protected-environment-in-which-to-gather</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>4747</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>attachment</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:attachment_url>http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/UNICEF-DRC-2013-Morton-Mwenga-Center-South-Kivu.jpg</wp:attachment_url>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attached_file</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2014/02/UNICEF-DRC-2013-Morton-Mwenga-Center-South-Kivu.jpg]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_metadata</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:5:{s:5:"width";i:622;s:6:"height";i:415;s:4:"file";s:59:"2014/02/UNICEF-DRC-2013-Morton-Mwenga-Center-South-Kivu.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:2:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:59:"UNICEF-DRC-2013-Morton-Mwenga-Center-South-Kivu-150x150.jpg";s:5:"width";i:150;s:6:"height";i:150;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}s:6:"medium";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:59:"UNICEF-DRC-2013-Morton-Mwenga-Center-South-Kivu-300x200.jpg";s:5:"width";i:300;s:6:"height";i:200;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:12:"Brett Morton";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:1120:"May 16, 2013.
UNICEF partner TPO operates two Child Friendly Spaces (CFS) in Mwenga Center, South Kivu, DRC, providing nearly 4,000 children aged 2-18 with a protected environment in which to gather, supervised by staff trained in child protection. Designed to support and encourage their freedom of expression, right to play, to learn, to be stimulated and to develop their capacities in a friendly and warm environment, Child Friendly Spaces also offer an opportunity to sensitize children on basic issues like hygiene and sanitation, as well as the importance of education.


“UNICEF funds our project in Mwenga, which is designed to reinforce the capacity of the community to respond on behalf of their vulnerable children,” explains Rwaha Rwakenga, a Social Worker for TPO, a Uganda-based NGO. “One day we’re not going to be here, but the community must carry on with serving and protecting their children. For this reason the community is involved not only in the CFS, but also in trainings and sensitizations to make sure everyone in the community is aware of the importance of this for their children.”";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:1368722699;s:9:"copyright";s:24:"©UNICEF DRC/2013/Morton";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:1110:"May 16, 2013.
UNICEF partner TPO operates two Child Friendly Spaces (CFS) in Mwenga Center, South Kivu, DRC, providing nearly 4,000 children aged 2-18 with a protected environment in which to gather, supervised by staff trained in child protection. Designed to support and encourage their freedom of expression, right to play, to learn, to be stimulated and to develop their capacities in a friendly and warm environment, Child Friendly Spaces also offer an opportunity to sensitize children on basic issues like hygiene and sanitation, as well as the importance of education.


?UNICEF funds our project in Mwenga, which is designed to reinforce the capacity of the community to respond on behalf of their vulnerable children,? explains Rwaha Rwakenga, a Social Worker for TPO, a Uganda-based NGO. ?One day we?re not going to be here, but the community must carry on with serving and protecting their children. For this reason the community is involved not only in the CFS, but also in trainings and sensitizations to make sure everyone in the community is aware of the importance of this for their children.?";}}]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>As part of the UNICEF/OCHA RRMP response to displacement in Mulamba, South Kivu, RRMP partner AVSI held a 4-day teacher amongst local schools, including E.P. Chiboba (pictured), where 95 of the 370 students were from displaced families, and gave $1,140 as the first part of 2 vouchers provided for improving the school structure. RRMP partner IRC constructed two blocks of latrines at E.P. Chiboba.</title>

		<title>2</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/la-suede-aux-cotes-de-lunicef-pour-proteger-les-enfants-contre-le-recrutement-et-lutilisation-par-des-forces-et-groupes-armes/2-16/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 24 Feb 2014 10:46:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/2.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>

		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4811</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-02-24 10:46:22</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-02-24 10:46:22</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>2-16</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>4807</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>attachment</wp:post_type>

	<item>
		<title>In 2008 in the United Republic of Tanzania, sunlight creates a shadow of children who are playing with hoops in the town of Morogoro, Morogoro Region.</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/la-suede-aux-cotes-de-lunicef-pour-proteger-les-enfants-contre-le-recrutement-et-lutilisation-par-des-forces-et-groupes-armes/in-2008-in-the-united-republic-of-tanzania-sunlight-creates-a-shadow-of-children-who-are-playing-with-hoops-in-the-town-of-morogoro-morogoro-region/</link>

	<item>
		<title>A child smiles in the village of Kobotu, in Bonthe District.In April 2010 in Sierra Leone, child and maternal mortality rates remain among the highest in the world. Nearly one out of every five children dies before the age of five, and a woman?s lifetime risk of maternal death is one in eight. Many health clinics lack ambulances, electricity, skilled personnel, and essential supplies, and many people simply cannot afford basic health services. Maternity services are particularly poor, with only 43 per cent of women giving birth in the presence of a skilled birth attendant, such as a doctor, nurse or midwife. The high prevalence of malnutrition, malaria, acute respiratory infections, preventable diseases, poverty and gender inequality also contribute to the high rates of death and illness among children and mothers. On 27 April, the Government inaugurated a programme that abolishes fees for primary health services to pregnant and lactating mothers and children under the age of five. Support for this programme comes from UNICEF, the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA), the World Health Organization (WHO), the World Bank, the African Development Bank, the European Union, Irish Aid and other partners. UNICEF is building clinics, supporting ambulance services, and providing essential drugs and supplies for obstetric care. UNICEF also supports preventative and curative health programmes, including vaccination campaigns, the distribution of insecticide-treated mosquito nets, the practice of exclusive breastfeeding and the promotion of hand-washing.</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/la-suede-aux-cotes-de-lunicef-pour-proteger-les-enfants-contre-le-recrutement-et-lutilisation-par-des-forces-et-groupes-armes/a-child-smiles-in-the-village-of-kobotu-in-bonthe-district-in-april-2010-in-sierra-leone-child-and-maternal-mortality-rates-remain-among-the-highest-in-the-world-nearly-one-out-of-every-five-ch/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 24 Feb 2014 10:46:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/UNICEFNYHQ2010-1016OLIVIER-ASSELIN.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[A child smiles in the village of Kobotu, in Bonthe District.

In April 2010 in Sierra Leone, child and maternal mortality rates remain among the highest in the world. Nearly one out of every five children dies before the age of five, and a woman’s lifetime risk of maternal death is one in eight. Many health clinics lack ambulances, electricity, skilled personnel, and essential supplies, and many people simply cannot afford basic health services. Maternity services are particularly poor, with only 43 per cent of women giving birth in the presence of a skilled birth attendant, such as a doctor, nurse or midwife. The high prevalence of malnutrition, malaria, acute respiratory infections, preventable diseases, poverty and gender inequality also contribute to the high rates of death and illness among children and mothers. On 27 April, the Government inaugurated a programme that abolishes fees for primary health services to pregnant and lactating mothers and children under the age of five. Support for this programme comes from UNICEF, the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA), the World Health Organization (WHO), the World Bank, the African Development Bank, the European Union, Irish Aid and other partners. UNICEF is building clinics, supporting ambulance services, and providing essential drugs and supplies for obstetric care. UNICEF also supports preventative and curative health programmes, including vaccination campaigns, the distribution of insecticide-treated mosquito nets, the practice of exclusive breastfeeding and the promotion of hand-washing.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Patricia Willocq_Exhaucé et Elli</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/blanc-ebene-celebrons-ensemble-la-difference/patricia-willocq_exhauce-et-elli/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 25 Feb 2014 10:21:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>Justine</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Patricia-Willocq_Exhaucé-et-Elli.jpg</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[Exhaucé et Elli sont des faux-jumeaux de 10 ans. Leur maîtresse sait que l'albinisme cause une mauvaise vision et leur permet de se lever pour lire au tableau. ]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>4831</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-02-25 10:21:23</wp:post_date>

	<item>
		<title>A 14 year old girl who was sexually abused and impregnated by an older man back in her village poses for a picture in the house where she lives with her sister in the town of Kailahun, Kailahun district, Sierra Leone on Friday March 18, 2011. &quot;I don&#039;t feel good about being pregnant, because I&#039;m just a small girl&quot;, she says. She had to drop out of school, but is hoping to go back and study nursing.</title>
