	<item>
		<title>Documents de référence</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/documents-reference/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 07 Dec 2013 16:38:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/?page_id=2595</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/31.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-2596" alt="31" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/31.jpg" width="917" height="610" /></a>

<strong>Veuillez cliquer sur les liens suivants pour télécharger les documents de référence et textes légaux mentionnés:</strong>

- <strong>Documents de référence pour la RDC:</strong>

<a href="/?p=4916" target="_blank">Plan d'action du Programme de Pays 2013 - 2017 entre le Gouvernement de la République Démocratique du Congo et l'Unicef (CPAP)</a>

<a href="http://www.unicef.org/evaldatabase/index_50916.html" target="_blank">Liste des rapports d'évaluation</a>

<a href="http://www.childinfo.org/files/MICS-RDC_2010_Final_Report_FR.pdf">Rapport Final de l'enquête par grappes à indicateurs multiples: MICS 2010</a>

<a href="http://www.leganet.cd/Legislation/JO/2009/L.09.001.10.01.09.htm" target="_blank">Loi n° 09/001 du 10 janvier 2009 portant protection de L'Enfant</a>

&nbsp;

-<strong> Documents de référence internationaux</strong>

<a href="http://www2.ohchr.org/french/law/crc.htm" target="_blank">Convention relative aux droits de l'enfant</a>

<a href="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Charte-africaine-des-droits-de-enfant.pdf" target="_blank">Charte africaine des droits de enfant</a>

<a href="http://www.unicef.org/french/protection/files/ParisPrincipesFrench310107.pdf" target="_blank">Les principes de Paris</a>

UNICEF - La situation des enfants dans le monde 2014- Chaque enfant compte : en <a href="http://www.unicef.org/french/sowc2014/numbers/" target="_blank">Anglais </a>et en <a href="http://www.unicef.org/french/publications/files/SOWC2014_FR.pdf" target="_blank">Français</a>

<a href="http://www.unicef.org/french/sowc2013/report.html" target="_blank">UNICEF - La situation des enfants dans le monde 2013 - Les enfants handicaps</a>

<a href="http://www.unicef.org/french/ffl/">Savoir pour sauver</a>]]></content:encoded>

<b>Bureaux Unicef en République Démocratique du Congo</b>

	<item>
		<title>Nos Blogueurs</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/nosbloggers/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 Dec 2013 15:25:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>stevebutton</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/?page_id=2783</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[one_third]
<h4>Barbara Bentein</h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/barbara/"><img class=" wp-image-2767 aligncenter" alt="56" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/56.jpg" width="390" height="263" /></a><em> Barbara Bentein est Représentante de l'UNICEF en RDC depuis 2011. Elle travaille depuis presque 30 ans pour l’Unicef, militant pour le respect des droits des enfants et un monde plus juste. Avant la RDC, elle a notamment été Représentante de l’Unicef à Madagascar, Maurice et Comores et Directrice régionale adjointe de l’Unicef pour l’Afrique de l’Ouest et Centrale.</em></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"> [/one_third][one_third]</p>

<h4>Sylvie Fouet</h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/sylvie-fouet/"><img class="aligncenter" alt="UNICEF Deputy Representative Sylvie Fouet visits PEAR+ (Programme Elargi d?Assistance aux Retours) activities in the Matanda area of South Kivu. PEAR Plus provides an integrated package of assistance and capacity building to communities; local and state authorities in the sectors of Health, Water, Hygiene and Sanitation, Education and Child Protection.Sectorial specific activities include the following: School reconstruction, support to transparent and equitable structure management, teacher-training, support to parent/teacher associations, provision of education kits and didactic material. Restoration and development of sustainable access to safe water and healthy environment; rehabilitation of health centres, reinforcement of health staff and directors? capacities; provision of basic medical necessities; support to vaccination campaigns and community-based treatment for malnutrition as well as the identification and strengthening child protection networks and responses are all part of the Programme.   Accompanied by peacebuilding activities and interventions designed to improve social cohesion, emphasis is put on governance activities (linked to social service provision) and conflict risk reduction in order to keep the Programme relevant to the evolving context and consequent needs. Increased community participation and ownership, as well as a reinforcement of the social contract between community, local and state authorities are increasingly key outputs of PEAR+?s approach.   A more explicit relationship with UNICEF?s long term programming provides a clear exit strategy and guarantees a degree of sustainability in the medium term, whilst a closer alignment with UNICEF?s emergency response mechanisms and the integration of sectorial emergency preparedness helps improve community resilience to the impact of conflict.  In recognition of the fluid nature in the east, the objective is to develop a way of working which supports social and economic rehabilitation; reinforces community resilience and eases the transition to emergency assistance or longer term support." src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Profil-bloggeur_Sylvie-Fouet-w.jpg" width="494" height="353" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Sylvie Fouet est Représentante Adjointe de l’UNICEF en RDC depuis 2011.  Elle travaille depuis presque 20 ans pour la coopération internationale, dont 10 ans avec Unicef, soutenant le respect des droits des enfants et une croissance inclusive.  Avant la RDC, elle a rejoint le siège de l'Unicef à New York, détachée en Europe à Bruxelles auprès de l’Union Européenne. Elle a aussi été postée en Iraq, dans les Territoires Occupés Palestiniens, au Soudan, en Syrie et au Yémen.</em>
[/one_third][one_third_last]</p>

<h4 style="text-align: left;">Ndiaga Seck</h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/ndiaga/"><img alt="Profil bloggeur_Ndiaga Seck" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Profil-bloggeur_Ndiaga-Seck-1024x731.jpg" width="375" height="268" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Ndiaga Seck est le Spécialiste en Communication de l’UNICEF à l’Est de la RDC. Il a une spécialisation en Études Humaines et Sociales, en Éducation et en Journalisme. Pendant les huit dernières années, il a travaillé pour IRIN et OCHA en Afrique de l’Ouest, OCHA et UNICEF en RDC. Son credo : « Un monde digne des enfants est à portée de main. Saisissons-le ! »</em></p>

<h4>[/one_third_last]</h4>
[separator]
[one_third]
<h4>Brett Morton</h4>
<a href="http://ponabana.com/author/brett/"><img class="aligncenter" alt="March 15, 2013 Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRC UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair. Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki  and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program ? co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando.  From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families.  Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners? relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations.  Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This ?Fair Approach? represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013." src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Profil-bloggeur_Brett-Morton21.jpg" width="320" height="247" /></a>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Brett Morton est consultant en Communication à l’UNICEF. En tant que photographe et designer, il a passé ces six dernières années à couvrir les situations d’urgence humanitaire et les activités de développement en Afrique Centrale et de l’Est; il croit que les images façonneront notre futur, mais maintient que ces mêmes images ne méritent pas que l’on sacrifie son humanité pour les obtenir. Son credo :« Lorsque nous ne sommes plus en mesure de changer la situation nous sommes invités à changer nous-mêmes» - V. Frankl</em></p>

<h4></h4>
<p style="text-align: center;">[/one_third][one_third]</p>

<h4>Sylvie Sona</h4>
<a href="http://ponabana.com/author/sylvie/"><img class="wp-image-2871 aligncenter" alt="Profil Sylvie" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Profil-Sylvie.jpg" width="375" height="300" /></a>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Sylvie Sona est Chargée de Communication à l’UNICEF/Zone Sud. Elle est journaliste de formation et aime beaucoup écrire. Elle a fait de la documentation et de la participation des enfants son cheval de bataille. Selon elle, il est indispensable de documenter systématiquement les expériences réussies et de mettre les enfants au cœur de toutes les interventions. Son credo : «  Donner la voix aux enfants ».</em></p>

<h4>[/one_third][one_third_last]</h4>
<h4>Adrien Majourel</h4>
<h4 style="font-size: 13px;"><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/adrien/"><img class="size-full wp-image-3201 aligncenter" alt="AM" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/AM1.jpg" width="541" height="408" /></a></h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Adrien Majourel est Officier de communication à l’Unicef RDC et administrateur de Pona Bana. Spécialisé en relations internationales et journalisme, il est convaincu de l’importance de donner de la voix aux enfants car bien souvent ce qu'ils voient échappe à des yeux d'adultes. Son crédo ? « Les enfants sont des énigmes lumineuses » Daniel Pennac</em></p>

<h4>[/one_third_last]</h4>
[separator]

[one_third]
<h4>Angele Bijanu</h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/angele/"><img class="wp-image-3109 aligncenter" alt="angele" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/angele.jpg" width="370" height="247" /></a> Angèle Bijanu Mpoyi est Administratrice chargée de la gestion de connaissance à l’UNICEF RDC. Economiste de formation, elle a également travaillé pour le PNUD RDC dans les provinces du Kasaï Oriental et du Nord Kivu d’abord en tant que chargée de programme puis Experte en Suivi et Evaluation. Passionnée par le changement du bien être social, elle milite pour l’équité et la justice surtout pour les plus vulnérables.</em></p>
 [/one_third][one_third]
<h4><span style="font-size: 1em;">Vanessa Wirth</span></h4>
<h4><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/vanessa/"><img class="aligncenter" alt="23504001_l_823d3a76f797e2d8fbee2efd0abf0f83" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/23504001_l_823d3a76f797e2d8fbee2efd0abf0f83.jpg" width="254" height="230" /></a></h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Vanessa Wirth est Chargée de Protection de l’Enfant à l’UNICEF et coordonne le groupe de travail sur la Protection de l’enfant en situation d’urgence à Kinshasa. Elle est spécialisée en droits humains et croit fermement que la protection des droits des enfants est la meilleure approche pour régler le problème de leur vulnérabilité et garantir une transition en douceur vers l’âge adulte. Son credo : « N’arrête jamais de rêver »</em>.</p>
[/one_third][one_third_last]
<h4>Eric-Alain Ategbo</h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="/?p=4666" target="_blank"><img class=" wp-image-3205 aligncenter" alt="ATEGBO" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/ATEGBO.jpg" width="387" height="348" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Eric-Alain Ategbo est le Spécialiste Nutrition Senior de l'UNICEF en RDC depuis Juin 2013. Il travaille pour l'UNICEF depuis 2003. Avant la RDC, il a travaillé en qualite de specialiste nutrition en Inde, en Ouganda et au Niger. Avant de joindre l'UNICEF Eric-Alain Ategbo était enseignant chercheur à l'Université nationale du Benin et a à son actif plusieurs publications scientifiques dans le domaine de la nutrition</em></p>

<h4>[/one_third_last]</h4>
[separator]

[one_third]
<h4>Violeta Cojocaru</h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/violeta/"><img class=" wp-image-3307 aligncenter" alt="violeta" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/violeta.jpg" width="498" height="332" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Violeta Cojocaru est responsable de la Communication pour le Développement (C4D) à l’UNICEF RDC depuis 2012. Elle dispose d'une expérience de 14 ans à l’Unicef en RDC, Niger et Moldavie et de 13 ans dans les media écrits et électroniques. Elle est convaincue qu'afin de stimuler un développement positif durable, la communication et le développement des capacités des communautés et des familles doivent être privilégiés. Cela donnera plus d'impact à nos actions.</em></p>
[/one_third][one_third]
<h4>Anne-Cecile Vialle</h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/anne-cecile/"><img alt="Profil bloggeur_Anne-Cecile Vialle2" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Profil-bloggeur_Anne-Cecile-Vialle2.jpg" width="370" height="278" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Anne-Cecile Vialle est chargée d'Assurance Qualité pour le bureau UNICEF RDC. Elle parcourt le pays pour appuyer les bureaux terrain dans l'execution des programmes, pour proposer au management des options visant à augmenter l'efficience et l'efficacité des procédures de travail internes, et in fine visant à optimiser la qualité et  durabilité des impacts de l'UNICEF pour les enfants et les femmes en RDC. Son leitmotiv: il y a toujours plus de solutions que de problèmes</em></p>
[/one_third][one_third_last]
<h4>Felicien Molima</h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/felicien/"><img class=" wp-image-3487 aligncenter" alt="Profil bloggeur_Felicien Molima" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Profil-bloggeur_Felicien-Molima.jpg" width="496" height="372" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Félicien est actuellement Spécialiste de la Planification et Cohésion au bureau de la zone Est à Goma depuis 2013. Il travaille à l'UNICEF DRC depuis 2001 comme Responsable de la Santé au bureau de Kisangani (6 ans), Chef de bureau de Kananga (2 ans) et Chef de bureau du Nord Kivu Maniema (3 ans) basé à Goma. Il aime les visites de terrain pour apprendre tant sur les acteurs de mise en œuvre que sur les bénéficiaires dans leur contexte.</em></p>

<h4><span style="font-size: 1em;">[/one_third_last]</span></h4>
[separator]

[one_third]
<h4><span style="font-size: 1em;">Blanqui Ntambwe Kabongo</span></h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/blanqui/"><img class=" wp-image-3708 aligncenter" alt="Profil bloggeur_Blanqui Ntambwe Kabongoweb" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Profil-bloggeur_Blanqui-Ntambwe-Kabongoweb.jpg" width="503" height="336" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Blanqui Ntambwe Kabongo est chargé du programme « Éducation et Consolidation de la Paix » à l’UNICEF/ RDC. Depuis 8 ans, il travaille dans le secteur de l’éducation respectivement au Ministère de l’Éducation de la RDC et à l’UNICEF. Il croit que donner à tous les enfants un accès équitable à une éducation de base de qualité est une stratégie efficace pour la construction d'une paix durable. Leitmotiv : “…..il n’est pas plus grand défi, ni de cause plus noble, que la protection de l’éducation !!!!” (M. Gordon Brown).</em></p>
[/one_third][one_third]
<h4>Bibiane Ambongo</h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/bibiane-ambongo/" target="_blank"><img class=" wp-image-3908 aligncenter" alt="Bibiane Ambongo" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Bibiane-Ambongo-2013.jpg" width="377" height="251" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Bibiane Ambongo est Spécialiste communication à l’UNICEF Kinshasa où elle travaille depuis de nombreuses années. Donner l’image d’une RDC qui se cherche et qui avance la préoccupe. Alors, si les enfants sont au centre de cette dynamique, il faut absolument les prendre par la main pour qu’ils révèlent leurs talents. Et Dieu sait s’ils en ont !</em></p>
[/one_third][one_third_last]
<h4>Serge Wingi</h4>
<h4><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/serge/"><img class=" wp-image-3931 aligncenter" alt="Profil bloggeur_Serge Wingi" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Profil-bloggeur_Serge-Wingi.jpg" width="374" height="250" /></a></h4>
<h4></h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Serge Wingi est Chargé de Communication et point focal Participation de l’Enfant à l’UNICEF RDC. Spécialisé en Sciences de la Communication et Marketing Social, sa ferme conviction est que les enfants peuvent changer le monde, si l'on investi en eux. </em><em>Sa passion: participer activement à la mobilisation de la communauté et des décideurs pour un plus grand investissement au niveau de l’enfance. "Il n’y a pas de succès sans successeur", dit-on.</em></p>

<h4>[/one_third_last]</h4>
[separator]

[one_third]
<h4>Justine Mounet</h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/justine/"><img class=" wp-image-4370 aligncenter" alt="Justine Mounet_Blog" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Justine-Mounet_Blog.jpg" width="508" height="338" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Justine Mounet est chargée de communication à l’UNICEF. Elle est convaincue que le plaidoyer et la participation sont essentiels pour atteindre la paix et la réalisation des droits de chacun. Elle s'est engagée aux côtés des enfants convaincue qu'ils sont la clé du changement. Son leitmotiv ? Il n’y pas de chemin menant au bonheur, le bonheur est le chemin.</em></p>
[/one_third][one_third]
<h4> Berta Travieso</h4>
<h4><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/berta-travieso/"><img class=" wp-image-4464 aligncenter" alt="Berta Travieso" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Profil-bloggeur_Berta-Travieso.jpg" width="373" height="248" /></a></h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Berta Travieso est la Chef du Bureau provincial du Sud-Kivu. Elle possède une Maîtrise en Affaires Humanitaires et travaille depuis 2 ans avec l'UNICEF en RDC. Berta croit que l’accès des enfants et des mères aux systèmes de santé, éducation et protection est la clé pour atteindre la paix et le développement durable. </em></p>
[/one_third][one_third_last]

&nbsp;
<h4>[/one_third_last]</h4>
<h6 style="text-align: center;">Les articles publiés représentent l’opinion de leurs auteurs et n’engagent pas la responsabilité de l’UNICEF. Les photos publiées sur Pona Bana sont la propriété de l'Unicef RDC - sauf mention contraire. Nous attachons un soin particulier à disposer de l'autorisation des personnes photographiées ou de leurs représentants légaux dans le respect de l'éthique et de la vie privée et dans un but strictement non lucratif. Dans l'éventualité où une personne photographiée ne souhaiterait plus apparaitre sur Pona Bana, nous nous engageons à retirer immédiatement la photo en question.</h6>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Enfants Blogueurs</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/bloggers/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 10 Dec 2013 08:10:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/?page_id=2823</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[one_third]
<h4><strong>Jonathan</strong></h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/jonathan/"><img class="wp-image-3395 aligncenter" alt="Nathan" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Nathan.jpg" width="557" height="371" /></a>
<em>Jonathan a 16 ans et il est enfant reporter de Kinshasa. Il étudie au collège Saint Joseph et aimerait devenir avocat pour défendre les droits des enfants. Son rêve? Que son pays "devienne un pays digne des enfants, un pays qui respecte les droits de l'enfant et qui les mettent au centre de tout.</em></p>
&nbsp;

[/one_third][one_third]
<h4><strong>Eunice</strong></h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/eunice/"><img class="wp-image-1890 aligncenter" alt="Eunice MUBA," src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Eunice-MUBA-1024x683.jpg" width="375" height="250" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Eunice a 14 ans et elle est enfant reporter de Kinshasa. Elle a représenté les enfants d'Afrique Centrale devant les leaders Africains au Sommet de l'Union Africaine à Addis Abeba en 2012. Dans son discours, elle a rappelé les droits de l'enfant à la survie, la liberté d'expression, l'éducation, la santé et a appelé à l'élaboration d'une stratégie pour prévenir les conflits armés qui affectent les enfants. Pourquoi enfant reporter? "Parce que je veux faire de mon pays un meilleur endroit où les enfants pourront vivre".</em></p>

<h4>[/one_third][one_third_last]</h4>
<h4><strong>Samy</strong></h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/samy/"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3214" alt="samy" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/samy.jpg" width="422" height="281" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Samy a 10 ans et il est en 5è année à l’école primaire Nsango Magulu, à 22 km de la ville de Kalemie. Il fait partie des 40 enfants reporters de la province du Nord Katanga formés en Août 2013. Il réside avec sa famille dans le camp de déplacés de Nsango Magulu, en provenance de Bendera.</em></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><em> </em>[/one_third_last]</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">[separator]</p>
[one_third]
<h4> <em> </em><strong style="font-size: 1em;">Rolande</strong></h4>
<a href="http://ponabana.com/author/rolande/"><img class="aligncenter" alt="Bandundu 4" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Bandundu-4.jpg" width="230" height="197" /></a>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Rolande a 13 ans et elle est enfant reporter à Bandundu. Elle s'engage aux côtés de ses amis pour lutter contre le mariage précoce et l'exploitation économique des enfants. Plus tard, elle sera institutrice pour transmettre ce qu'elle a appris</em></p>
&nbsp;

[/one_third][one_third]
<h4><strong> Nathan</strong></h4>
<h4></h4>
<em><a href="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/IMG_6266.jpg"><img class="alignnone  wp-image-5174" alt="IMG_6266" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/IMG_6266.jpg" width="373" height="249" /></a></em>

<em>Nathan a 15 ans et il est au Collège Notre Dame du Congo à Kinshasa. Passionné de football, il joue milieu pour "organiser le jeu". Plus tard, il veut être un avocat reconnu et travailler pour la Cour Pénale Internationale. Sa devise: "Que tous nous soyons un!"</em>
<h4>[/one_third][one_third_last]</h4>
<h4><strong>Bora</strong></h4>
<h4><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/bora/" target="_blank"><img class=" wp-image-4308 aligncenter" alt="IMG_6748" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/IMG_6748.jpg" width="504" height="336" /></a></h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Bora a 14 ans et elle est enfant reporter à Lubumbashi. Plus tard elle veut être criminologue. Aujourd'hui elle s'attache à rassembler les enfants reporters de toutes les provinces pour que leur voix résonne jusqu'au bout du monde!</em></p>

<h4><em>. </em>[/one_third_last]</h4>
[separator]

[one_third]
<h4><strong>Carine</strong></h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/carine/"><img class=" wp-image-4328 aligncenter" alt="carine" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/carine.jpg" width="374" height="250" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Carine a 18 ans et elle est Enfant Reporter de Goma. Elle est en 1ere avec une spécialisation en informatique. Passionnée de prise d'images et de rédaction d'histoires à caractère humain, Carine croit qu'à travers ces canaux elle pourra contribuer au respect des droits des enfants de la RDC en général et du Nord-kivu en particulier.</em></p>
&nbsp;

[/one_third][one_third]
<h4><em> </em><strong>Fatouma</strong></h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/fatuma/" target="_blank"><img class=" wp-image-4559 aligncenter" alt="Fatuma Feza" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Fatuma-Feza.jpg" width="381" height="254" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Fatuma a 12 ans et demi. Elle est élève en cinquième année de l'Ecole Primaire Magulu Muyembo, dans le village de Sango Malumbi, à Kalemie dans le Katanga. Avec ses camarades, elle mène des plaidoyers sur les droits des enfants et la paix, dans son école et son village.</em></p>

<h4>[/one_third][one_third_last]</h4>
<h4><strong>Sofia</strong></h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/sofia/"><img class=" wp-image-4978 aligncenter" alt="Sofia" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Sofia.jpg" width="386" height="257" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Sofia a 15 ans et vit à Paris, en France. Élève au Lycée en classe de 2nde, elle aimerait devenir avocate. Elle aime l'histoire, la géographie, apprendre de nouvelles langues et cuisiner. L'année dernière elle a participé au Google Hangout organisé à l'occasion du Sommet de la Francophonie de Kinshasa entre les enfants de RDC et du monde francophone.</em></p>

<h4><em style="font-size: 1em;"> </em></h4>
<h4><span style="font-size: 1em;">[/one_third_last]</span></h4>
[separator]

[one_third]
<h4><strong>Miradi</strong></h4>
<em><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/miradi/"><img class="alignnone  wp-image-5171" alt="IMG_6313" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/IMG_6313.jpg" width="373" height="249" /></a></em>

<em>Passionné de dessin, Miradi a 13 ans et étudie au Collège Saint Joseph à Kinshasa. Plus tard, il voudrait être archéologue ou chercheur scientifique. Pour lui, être enfant reporter "c'est avant tout défendre les droits des autres enfants".</em>

&nbsp;

[/one_third][one_third]
<h4><strong> Merveille</strong></h4>
<a href="http://ponabana.com/author/merveille/"><img class="alignnone  wp-image-5172" alt="IMG_6380" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/IMG_6380.jpg" width="373" height="249" /></a>

<em>Merveille a 17 ans et elle étudie à l'Institut Bambous à Kinshasa. Après, elle veut aller à l'Université et devenir nutritionniste. Selon elle, "il ne faut pas se limiter au rôle d'enfant reporter mais poursuivre cet engagement pour les enfants dans la vie d'adulte".</em>
<h4>[/one_third][one_third_last]</h4>
<strong style="font-size: 1em;">Osé</strong>

<a href="http://ponabana.com/author/ose/" target="_blank"><img class="wp-image-5659 aligncenter" alt="Ose2" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Ose2.jpg" width="154" height="177" /></a>

<em>Osé est élève de quatrième année littéraire à l’Institut de Mbandaka dans la province de l’Équateur. Il a 15 ans et est enfant reporter depuis janvier 2013.
</em>
<h4><em> </em></h4>
<h4>[/one_third_last]</h4>
[separator]

[one_third]
<h4><strong>Deo</strong></h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/deo/"><img class=" wp-image-5685 aligncenter" alt="Deo" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Deo.jpg" width="180" height="224" /></a></p>
<em>Déo a 16 ans et étudie au collège KIVUVU a Bandundu. Il adore le football et les mathématiques. Plus tard, il veut être professeur et dispenser le cours des mathématiques aux étudiants a l'université. Etre enfant Reporter pour lui est une opportunité qui lui permet de plaider sur les différents problèmes d'abus que subissent les autres enfants.</em>

&nbsp;

[/one_third][one_third]
<h4><strong> </strong></h4>
<h4>[/one_third][one_third_last]</h4>
<strong> </strong>

&nbsp;
<h4>[/one_third_last]</h4>
[separator]
<h6 style="text-align: center;">Les articles publiés représentent l’opinion de leurs auteurs et n’engagent pas la responsabilité de l’UNICEF. Les photos publiées sur Pona Bana sont la propriété de l'Unicef RDC - sauf mention contraire. Nous attachons un soin particulier à disposer de l'autorisation des personnes photographiées ou de leurs représentants légaux dans le respect de l'éthique et de la vie privée et dans un but strictement non lucratif. Dans l'éventualité où une personne photographiée ne souhaiterait plus apparaitre sur Pona Bana, nous nous engageons à retirer immédiatement la photo en question.</h6>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Notre Travail</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/notre-travail/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 10 Dec 2013 13:03:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/?page_id=2925</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[one_half] <strong>Tout ce qu'il faut savoir sur le travail de l'UNICEF et de ses partenaires en République Démocratique du Congo.</strong>

Dans cette section vous trouverez l'ensemble des articles publiés par nos spécialistes, partenaires et invités. Une vision unique et authentique du travail accompli sur le terrain.

Pour chaque thème sur lequel l'UNICEF travaille en RDC nous vous proposons un état des lieux, les principaux chiffres clefs, les résultats obtenus et les prochaines étapes.

Les principaux programmes sont également détaillés et une carte vous permettra de découvrir où sont situés les bureau de l'UNICEF sur l'ensemble du territoire de la RDC.

[/one_half]

[one_half_last]

[accordion]

[section title="Nos articles"]<a href="/?cat_ID=126">L'ensemble des articles écrits par nos spécialistes, partenaires et invités. Une vision unique et authentique du travail accompli sur le terrain pour les enfants de la RDC.</a> [/section]

[section title="Nos thèmes"]<a href="/?page_id=2932">Pour chaque thème sur lequel l'UNICEF travaille en RDC, retrouvez un état des lieux, les principaux chiffres clefs et les résultats obtenus. </a>[/section]

[section title="Principaux programmes"]<a href="/?page_id=2940">Une fiche descriptive présentant les éléments à retenir sur chacun des principaux programmes mis en place par l'UNICEF en RDC</a>.[/section]

[section title="Présence sur le terrain"]<a href="/?page_id=2747">Une carte de la RDC présentant les différents bureaux de l'UNICEF sur l'ensemble du territoire.</a> [/section]

[section title="Communiqué de presse"] <a href="/?cat_ID=5">Les derniers communiqués de presse publiés par l'UNICEF en RDC</a>[/section]

[/accordion] [/one_half_last]]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Nos thèmes</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/nos-themes/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 10 Dec 2013 13:21:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/?page_id=2932</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: justify;">[one_half] <strong>L'UNICEF en RDC travaille sur 7 "thèmes" prioritaires : Education, Santé, Nutrition, Protection, Eau et assainissement, Urgences et Participation.</strong></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">Pour chacun de ces thèmes, nous vous proposons une description générale du thème accompagné des principaux chiffres clefs, enjeux majeurs, principales avancées et des perspectives attendues.</p>
[/one_half]

[one_half_last]

[section title="Participation"] <a href="/?page_id=4232" target="_blank">L'essentiel pour comprendre les enjeux liés à la participation en RDC</a>[/section]

	<item>
		<title>Principaux programmes</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/principaux-programmes/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 10 Dec 2013 13:42:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/?page_id=2940</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[one_half] <strong>Des outils innovants et flexibles pour améliorer la situation des enfants de la RDC. </strong>
<p style="text-align: justify;">Dans cette section vous trouverez quelques uns des programmes "emblématiques" de l'action que nous menons avec nos partenaires sur le terrain afin de répondre au mieux aux besoins des enfants de la RDC.</p>
[/one_half]

[one_half_last]

[accordion]

[section title="Réponse Rapide au Mouvement de Population - RRMP"] <a href="/?page_id=1853">Evaluations rapides des besoins et assistance intégrée aux populations vulnérables affectées par les déplacements, le retour et/ou les catastrophes naturelles.</a> [/section]

[section title="Ecoles et Villages assainis"]<a href="/?page_id=2559">Objectif: Réduire la mortalité infantile et la propagation des maladies d'origine hydriques, ainsi qu’un accès à l’eau potable favorisé dans les zones rurales et périurbaines</a>[/section]

[section title="Enfants Reporters"]<a href="/?page_id=2505">L’UNICEF, en appui au gouvernement congolais, donne la parole aux jeunes en RDC pour qu’ils défendent les droits de l’enfant et soient acteurs des décisions qui les concernent</a>.[/section]

[/accordion] [/one_half_last]]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Water and Sanitation</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/water-and-sanitation/?lang=en</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 27 Dec 2013 15:27:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/?page_id=3357</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/ZAI_Mbandaka_23-March-2011-307.jpg"><img alt="ZAI_Mbandaka_23 March 2011 307" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/ZAI_Mbandaka_23-March-2011-307.jpg" width="640" height="475" /></a>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>IMPROVE WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION</strong></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">In DRC as in many countries around the world, UNICEF is working to improve water supply and sanitation in schools and communities and to promote hygienic practices . We support multiple and diverse activities and cooperate with many partners, including families, communities, governments and organizations sharing the same values.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>INTERVENTION IN EMERGENCIES</strong></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">We provide emergency assistance to communities and people at risk of not being supplied with water and threatened by disease emergency. All programs of UNICEF's water and sanitation are designed to contribute to the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals related to water and sanitation : reduce, by 2015, the proportion of people without sustainable access to safe water and basic sanitation.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>3357</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-12-27 15:27:10</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2013-12-27 15:27:10</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>water-and-sanitation</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>

	<item>
		<title>Water and Sanitation - The way forward in DRC</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/water-and-sanitation/water-and-sanitation-the-way-forward-in-drc/?lang=en</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 27 Dec 2013 15:33:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/?page_id=3361</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img alt="NYHQ2000-0682" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/UNI35078.jpg" />

<strong> 4 MILLION PEOPLE WILL GAIN ACCESS TO IMPROVED WATER AND SANITATION SERVICES BY 2017</strong>
<p style="text-align: justify;">The UNICEF Country Programme 2013-2017 extended the Healthy Villages and Schools program to almost 6,000 villages and 1,500 schools, the equivalent of approximately 4 million people gaining first-time access to improved WASH services.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">By September 30, 2019, UNICEF planned to reach 7500 villages which will have committees acting to protect and maintain their healthy environment</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">The HVHS programme is scaling up to be operational in 250 out of the 515 Health Zones (49%). The second phase of the Healthy Villages and Schools program is focusing on sustainability, including the sustainability of hardware WASH installations; institutional capacity, accountability and obligation, health outcomes, and the scalability of quality results. A strategy is being defined to promote complementarity between the programme and projects of other government institutions, NGOs or the private sector.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">To promote transition between emergency and development, new strategies are under discussion within the different stakeholders. UNICEF is also supporting the 2013-2017 New Multisectoral Strategic Plan for the Elimination of Cholera in DRC.</p>
&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Water and Sanitation - Key statistics</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/water-and-sanitation/water-and-sanitation-key-statistics/?lang=en</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 27 Dec 2013 15:39:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/?page_id=3365</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: justify;"><a href="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/04/110921095256.jpg"><img class="alignleft" alt="110921095256" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/04/110921095256-242x300.jpg" width="242" height="300" /></a>DRC is not on track to reach the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) in water and sanitation. The achievement of Goal 7 would require reaching 72% access to drinking water and 58% access to improved sanitation by 2015. Currently 47% of the population has access to safe drinking water (83% urban and 31% rural), while only 14% of the population has access to adequate sanitation facilities (36% urban and 4% rural) according to MICS 2010. Thus to meet the MDGs 17.5 million people in DRC would need to gain access to water and 30.8 million people must gain access to sanitation by 2015.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>MAIN KEY STATISTICS</strong></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>-</strong> <strong>47 %</strong> of the total population has access to safe drinking water, and <strong>14%</strong> access to improved sanitation (MICS 2010).</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">- In rural areas, water coverage is <strong>31 %</strong>; rural improved sanitation <strong>4%</strong> (MICS 2010).</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">- In addition, there are cholera epidemics in endemic cholera prone zone every year in the provinces of Katanga, Oriental, North and South Kivu. DRC is also facing outbreaks in non-endemic areas along the river Congo or cross border with Zambia/Congo Brazzaville. In August 2013, 21 264 cholera cases with 321 deaths have been reported in total and half of them came from Katanga Province and cross-border with Zambia (2014 HNO).</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">- <strong>2.7 millions of IDP’s</strong> are facing challenges to meet their right to get access to safe water, improved sanitation and hygiene</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>3365</wp:post_id>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Water and Sanitation - Key Challenges in DRC</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/water-and-sanitation/water-and-sanitation-key-challenges-in-drc/?lang=en</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 27 Dec 2013 15:43:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/?page_id=3370</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignleft" alt="2" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/04/2-300x199.jpg" width="300" height="199" />
<p style="text-align: justify;">The water and sanitation sector is weakened by a fragmented political structure. There are currently 6 different government bodies implicated, through 6 separate ministries. Major agencies include: REGIDESO for urban water (Ministry of Energy); National Hydraulic Service for rural water (SNHR), Ministry of Rural Development; PNA for sanitation (Ministry of the Environment) and the 9th Bureau of the Ministry of Health working in both water and sanitation. To facilitate the coordination of the water and sanitation sector, a separate agency, the CNAEA, was created in the 1990s and is based at the Ministry of Planning.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">Support was given to the National Committee for Action on Water and Sanitation under the Ministry of Plan (CNAEA), for DRC to join 35 other countries as members of the Sanitation and Water for All initiative. The Government committed at the Washington high level conference in April 2012 to strengthen WASH institutions and related human resources in 2013-2014. UNICEF participates in the WASH Donor Group and the Hygiene Thematic Group. Among the priorities promoted by UNICEF are to push for support to the government strategy on the elimination of cholera in endemic and epidemic areas.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Water and Sanition - Major achievements in DRC</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/water-and-sanitation/water-and-sanition-major-achievements-in-drc/?lang=en</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 27 Dec 2013 15:52:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/?page_id=3372</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/340.jpg"><img alt="340" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/340.jpg" width="615" height="440" /></a>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>In the WASH sector, Unicef and its partner obtained the following results:</strong></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">1. Increased government capacity and development of national strategies towards improving rural water, sanitation and hygiene throughout 11 provinces and 250 health zones of DRC.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">2. The national “Healthy Village and Healthy School” programme follows a community-driven demand-led strategy which gives families the opportunity to make informed choices while strengthening their resilience.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">3. At the end of June 2013 the VEA programme was operational in 11 Provinces, 212 Health Zones, and 5289 villages, of which 3256 were certified “Healthy Villages” and 1425 schools, of which 1054 were certified “Healthy Schools”. These results translate into the concrete results of 2,273,198 new persons gaining access to a healthy environment by surpassing minimum water, sanitation and hygiene targets.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">4. UNICEF WASH emergency programme assisted more than 800 000 persons in cholera-prone zones with preventive as well as WASH cholera-response packages (MYR Sitrep 2013). With the support of RRMP (Reponse Rapide aux Mouvements de Population, UNICEF DRC’s major emergency programme), 295,144 people were given access to water, sanitation and hygiene in emergency from January to Octobre 2013.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">5. In 2013, as UNICEF cluster lead agency for emergency WASH interventions, the WASH Cluster, with their members, coordinated the response to assist more than 4.5 million persons (MYR Sitrep 2013) to get access the WASH packages in order to save life, reduce vulnerability and meet the basic needs.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Healthy villages and schools</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/healthy-villages-and-schools/?lang=en</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 27 Dec 2013 16:11:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/?page_id=3379</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/eva.jpg"><img alt="eva" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/eva-1024x349.jpg" width="625" height="213" /></a>

<strong>BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVE</strong>
<p style="text-align: justify;">Despite the presence of water resources in the DRC, 51 million Congolese people still lack access to safe drinking water - nearly three-quarters of the country's population. Poor access to drinking water and lack of education on hygiene and sanitation are among the main causes of high morbidity and mortality, especially among children under 5 years.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">In order to address these issues water, hygiene and sanitation issues, the DRC government has reinforced its efforts to improve the health conditions in the most vulnerable areas. Thus in 2006 , with the support of its partners including UNICEF, he set up the Healthy Village Programme. An extension to the schools through the Healthy School Programme, has been launched in 2008.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">The main objective of the Healthy villages and schools programme is to reduce infant mortality and the spread of water-borne diseases, as well as improve access to drinking water favored in rural and suburban areas.</p>
<strong>WHAT IS A HEALTHY VILLAGE ?</strong>

1. A village with a dynamic committee

2. At least 80% of the population has access to drinking water

3. At least 80% of households use sanitary latrines

4. At least 80% of plots are clean

5. At least 60% of the population washes their hands with soap or ash before eating and after visiting the latrine

6. At least 70% of the population understands the pattern of disease transmission from fecal matter and the associated preventive measures

7. The village is cleaned at least once a month

<strong>AND A HEALTHY SCHOOL ?</strong>

1. 100% of teachers are trained in the "Healthy Schools" strategy, Health and Environmental Education, and 100% of Parent Involvement Committee members have received awareness training

2. At least 80% of student textbooks are available: 1 textbook for every 2 students or 1 guide per teacher

3. At least 1 entrance for every 40 girls and 1 entrance for every 50 boys, at least 80% of latrines are sanitary

4. 100% availability of drinking water and at least 80% of students wash their hands with soap or ash

5. The schoolyard and classrooms are cleaned once a day and trash is thrown in a refuse pit

6. 100% of health and environment patrollers elected in the schools have received awareness training and are operational

<strong>A STEP-BY-STEP GUIDE TO THE "HEALTHY VILLAGE" APPROACH</strong>

<b></b>1. The community learns of the programme and collectively decides to adopt it, then submits a formal request to the health zone.

2. A statement of agreement between the community and the health zone is signed.

3. The health zone provides training to 20 volunteers, then the community elects a village committee.

4. Health zone officials investigate the behaviours, attitudes and practices of village households.

5. The community analyses its hygiene and sanitation using community mapping, observation walks, 3 categories of classification for hygiene conditions and an analysis of fecal-oral transmission routes.

6. The community develops a Community Action Plan and prioritises interventions.

7. The community takes action to improve access to water and sanitation. Volunteers promote good hygiene practices.

8. The final investigation: the office of the health zone conducts a study of the community's new knowledge, attitudes and practices.

9. The chief medical officer of the health zone checks whether the village meets the standards required to be designated a Healthy Village. If this is the case, the chief medical officer provides the village with a certificate as part of a celebration.

<strong>You will find more useful information on the healthy village and school official website:</strong>

<a href="http://www.ecole-village-assainis.cd/"><cite>www.<b>ecole</b>-<b>village</b>-<b>assainis</b>.cd/</cite></a>‎]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Key Statistics</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/key-statistics/?lang=en</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 27 Dec 2013 16:38:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[one_half] <strong>Main key statistic on the situation of DRC's children.</strong>

In this section you will find essential data to better apprehend the context, the progresses that have been made ​​and the way forward to ensure that all children's rights are respected in the DRC.

&nbsp;

[/one_half]

		<wp:post_id>3385</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>Bloggers</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/bloggers-2/?lang=en</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 27 Dec 2013 16:48:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/?page_id=3388</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[one_third]
<h4><strong>Jonathan</strong></h4>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://ponabana.com/author/jonathan/"><img class="aligncenter" alt="Profil Jonathan" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Profil-Jonathan.jpg" width="373" height="249" /></a><em>  Jonathan is 16 years old and he is a youth reporter Kinshasa. He studied at Saint Joseph College and wants to become a lawyer to defend the children's rights. His dream? That his country "become a country fit for children, a country that respects the rights of the children and put them at the center of everything."</em></p>
&nbsp;

[/one_third][one_third]
<h4><strong>Eunice</strong></h4>
<a href="http://www.kidsareheroes.org/heroes/Eunice-Muba.php"><img class="aligncenter" alt="Eunice MUBA," src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Eunice-MUBA-1024x683.jpg" width="375" height="250" /></a>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Eunice is 14 years old and she is a youth reporter in Kinshasa. She represented Central Africa's children  at the African Union Summit in Addis Ababa in 2012. In her speech </em><em>to African leaders</em><em>, she recalled children's rights to survival, freedom of expression, education, health and called for a strategy to prevent armed conflicts which affect the child. Why youth reporter? "Because I want to make my country a better place for children to live."</em></p>

<h4>[/one_third][one_third_last]</h4>
<h4><strong>Samy</strong></h4>
<a href="http://ponabana.com/author/samy/"><img class="aligncenter" alt="samy" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/samy.jpg" width="422" height="281" /></a>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Samy is 10 years old and he is 5th grade in </em><em>Nsango Magulu </em><em>Elementary school, 22 km from the town of Kalemie. He is one of the 40 youth reporters trained in the province of North Katanga in August 2013. He lives with his family in the camps for displaced perons of Nsango Magulu and is from Bendera.</em></p>
<em> </em>[/one_third_last]

[separator]

[one_third]
<h4> <em> </em><strong>Rolande</strong></h4>
<a href="http://ponabana.com/author/rolande/"><img class="aligncenter" alt="Bandundu 4" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/Bandundu-4.jpg" width="230" height="197" /></a>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em>Rolande is 13 years old and she is a  youth reporter in Bandundu. Along with her friends, she is comitted to fight against early marriage and the economic exploitation of children. Later, she will be a teacher to convey what she has learned</em></p>
&nbsp;

	<item>
		<title>Education</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/education/?lang=en</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 02 Jan 2014 15:59:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/?page_id=3521</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/9.jpg"><img title="Photo © AVSI/2012/Morton" alt="9" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/9.jpg" width="775" height="620" /></a>

<strong>EDUCATION IS A FUNDAMENTAL HUMAN RIGHT</strong>

Education is a fundamental human right: Every girl and boy in every country is entitled to it. Quality education is critical to development both of societies and of individuals, and it helps pave the way to a successful and productive future. When all children have access to a quality education rooted in human rights and gender equality, it creates a ripple effect of opportunity that influences generations to come.

<strong>REDUCING INEQUITIES AND DISCRIMINATION</strong>

Education ends generational cycles of poverty and disease and provides a foundation for sustainable development. A quality basic education equips girls and boys with the knowledge and skills they need to adopt healthy lifestyles, protect themselves from HIV and take an active role in social, economic and political decision-making as they transition to adolescence and adulthood. Educated adults are more likely to have smaller and healthier families, to be informed about appropriate child-rearing practices and to ensure that their children start school on time and ready to learn.

Education based on human rights also helps to root out some of society’s persistent inequities. These deprive millions of children, particularly girls, of quality education – and therefore subject them to a life of missed opportunities. Ensuring equity in education builds a foundation for equal opportunity, economic growth, employment creation and productivity.

<strong>AN OPPORTUNITY TO SURVIVE, DEVELOP AND REACH THEIR FULL POTENTIAL</strong>

UNICEF supports development of national capacities to reduce gender and other disparities and discrimination against children who are out of school. This includes girls; children from poor households or living in rural areas; children belonging to ethnic and linguistic minorities, indigenous groups and castes facing discrimination; and children affected by HIV/AIDS or disabilities.

For UNICEF, equity means that all children have an opportunity to survive, develop and reach their full potential, without discrimination, bias or favoritism. This interpretation is consistent with the Convention on the Rights of the Child, which pledges the fundamental rights of every child.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Education - The way forward in DRC</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/education/education-the-way-forward-in-drc/?lang=en</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 02 Jan 2014 16:12:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/?page_id=3525</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/14.jpg"><img alt="Pupils on their way to school; at Plateau neighborhood, in Kikwit." src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/14.jpg" width="645" height="430" /></a>

<strong>"REDUCING THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN OUT OF SCHOOL"</strong>
<div style="text-align: justify;">

Following the Education First High level meeting, a number of partners have pledged to support the acceleration of primary education in DRC. Within the framework of the Interim Education Plan, the recently approved GPE funding ($ 100 millions), complemented by other external resources (including UNICEF’s , DFID AFD, World Bank, USAID, Educate and Child/Qatar) will contribute a number of measures to fill existing financing gaps. UNICEF and DFID are supporting the elaboration of the Equity in Education policy and strategy to reduce the number of children out of school. AFD will support recurrent costs (especially teachers’ salaries, construction and rehabilitation of schools as well as quality education); USAID will also contribute to the Education First Initiative, focusing on Equitable Access and Quality.

&nbsp;

Important steps to take include an increase of budget allocations for the education sector, increased investments in access and quality, especially dealing with the systemic challenges affecting teachers. . A budget monitoring and an accountability systemneed strengthening, including through promotion of local community participation in policy dialogue. . The capacity of all stakeholders in relation to financial and program management must be enhanced. The Information System for Management Education (EMIS) needs to be strengthened and government investments made to sustain routine collection and analysis of data. . UNICEF is currently supporting EMIS capacity strengthening at decentralized levels.

</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Education - Key Statistics</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/education/education/?lang=en</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 02 Jan 2014 16:29:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/?page_id=3531</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/16.jpg"><img alt="16" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/16.jpg" width="773" height="515" /></a>

<b> </b>
<table border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="223"><b>Indicateurs</b><b></b></td>
<td valign="top" width="258"><b>Données</b></td>
<td valign="top" width="190"><b>Année/Source</b><b></b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="223">Preschool enrollment rate 3.6%</td>
<td valign="top" width="258">3,6%</td>
<td valign="top" width="190">Statistical Yearbook 2010-2011</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="223">Net Intake Rate</td>
<td valign="top" width="258">B=59%  G=52,9% T=56%</td>
<td valign="top" width="190">Statistical Yearbook 2010-2011</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="223">Gross enrollment rate</td>
<td valign="top" width="258">B=99,6% G=85,8% T=92,7%</td>
<td valign="top" width="190">Statistical Yearbook 2010-2011</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="223">Completion rate</td>
<td valign="top" width="258">B=68,5% G=49,1% T=58,8%</td>
<td valign="top" width="190">Statistical Yearbook 2010-2011</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="223">Parity Index</td>
<td valign="top" width="258">0,86</td>
<td valign="top" width="190">Statistical Yearbook 2010-2011</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="223">Children (5-17 years) out of  school</td>
<td valign="top" width="258">7.4 millions (52% filles) ; 60% ont 6 et 7 ans</td>
<td valign="top" width="190">Out of school Study 2012</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="223">Transition from primary to secondary</td>
<td valign="top" width="258">74.7% (Gross rate)</td>
<td valign="top" width="190">Statistical Yearbook 2010-2011</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td valign="top" width="223">Gross enrollment  rate in secondary school</td>
<td valign="top" width="258">38,5%</td>
<td valign="top" width="190">Statistical Yearbook 2010-2011</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: justify;">Despite decades of economic and political crisis the coverage and performance of the education sector has increased in recent years. Although there is gender parity in enrolment at at primary level, important differences between provinces remain.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>EDUCATION COSTS ARE TOO HIGH</strong></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">Primary school completion rate has reached 58,8% in 2011. In spite of the fee free primary education policy,  education costs remains high for families. Government transfers to support the functionning of schools and administrative offices remains insufficient. Pupils are  requested to pay different types of fees including teachers’ salaries.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">After Nigeria and Ethiopia,  DRC has the largest number of school-children in sub-Saharan Africa. The 2012 Out of School study shows a direct relationship between the enrolment of children in school and the income status of a household. In poor families the access and retention of children is low, especially in rural areas, gender parity is 0.86 – and of those who reach university level, girls constitute only 30%</p>
&nbsp;

<a href="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/EAD-2012-Enfants-en-dehors-de-lEcole-par-province-en-RDC.jpg"><img alt="EAD 2012 Enfants en dehors de l'Ecole par province en RDC" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/EAD-2012-Enfants-en-dehors-de-lEcole-par-province-en-RDC.jpg" width="960" height="720" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Education - Key Challenges in DRC</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/education/education-key-challenges-in-drc/?lang=en</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 02 Jan 2014 16:50:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/?page_id=3536</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/13.jpg"><img alt="Girl smiling - the flower she wears on her forehead is for the International Women Day; at Kakoy Primary School, in Kakoy." src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/13.jpg" width="630" height="420" /></a>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>SCHOOL COSTS ARE TOO HIGH</strong></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">In 2010 a policy of school fee abolition was announced by the President yet its impact is limited Parents continue to bear the main burden of direct and indirect cost, including the running costs of schools and the incentives for teachers who are not on the official payroll or who are paid late. . UNICEF is assisting in the formative evaluation of this policy with a view to guiding policy re-orientations.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>EDUCATION IN THE NATIONAL BUDGET</strong></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">Over 2008-2010, the budget of the education sector accounted for about 3% of GDP and only 8.5% of the national budget. Although the education’s share of the national budget has increased to 13% in 2013, most domestic funding goes to pay salaries (see Interim Education Plan 2012/2016)  The body of teachers represents 80% of the size of the education public sector, while funding for other items such as operations and investments remain weak and often ineffective. There is an estimated gap of $270 million that is yet to be funded by the Government’s Interim Education Plan.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>QUALITY AND INVESTMENTS</strong></p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">Children lack basic competencies and the more a student progresses on the educational ladder, the lower the retention rates. Major quality concerns include the lack of investments in initial teacher training, and incentives to attract good quality persons into the teaching profession. The curriculum is over-loaded with content that is irrelevant for 21<sup>st</sup> century needs , especially in terms of employable economic, social and emotional skills . UNICEF and partners are working toegther to support improvement of reading literacy, numeracy and life skills as core foundational skills. UNICEF is also supporting a new Peace Building in Education Programme which will strengthen the resilience of children, their parents and institutions to prevent, manage, and deal with conflicts and violence in and around schools.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>3536</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-01-02 16:50:38</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-01-02 16:50:38</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>education-key-challenges-in-drc</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>3521</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>

		<wp:postmeta>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Education - Major achievements in DRC</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/education/education-major-achievements-in-drc/?lang=en</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 02 Jan 2014 16:57:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/?page_id=3541</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img alt="15" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/15.jpg" width="718" height="478" />

<strong>IMPROVEMENT OF THE EDUCATION QUALITY</strong>

Over the past four years (2008-2012), UNICEF has contributed over $ 80 million U.S. dollars to increase access and improve the quality of education for  more than 4 million children. During the 2012-2013 school-year UNICEF has invested more than 1.7 million dollars in school kits for 623,466 students and 14,922 teachers in the South and the West of the country.

<strong>EDUCATION IN EMERGENCIES</strong>

In the conflict-affected East, direct cash transfer of funds to schools was done for a total of $ 650,000 in favor of school kits for 346.773 students and 7,677 teachers. To promote education in emergency and transition situations UNICEF trained teachers and parents on learner-centred methodologies in core curricula areas and psychosocial support for children affected by the conflict, thereby contributing to improved learner performance.

Among the 2.4 million internally displaced persons (IDP), half are children and 690,000 are old enough to attend primary school. The enrollment rate of children in IDP camps is around 37% (Sources: OCHA IDP Factsheet, July 2012). However, enrolment rates in the provinces affected by conflict compare favourably with non-emergency provinces thanks to emergency education support provided by various donors.

<strong>ENHANCED PARTNERSHIPS</strong>

At policy level, UNICEF has contributed to improve knowledge on equity issues in education and the elaboration of policies and strategies to combat exclusion in education. UNICEF has also been instrumental in improvements in sector coordination among all partners as well as the development of a policy dialogue agenda to accompany sector reform. Sector analysis is currently ongoing with UNICEF support, which for the first time will produce a conflict-sensitive analysis to be used in the elaboration of the new education sector plan.

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Youth Reporters</title>
		<link>http://ponabana.com/youth-reporters/?lang=en</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 02 Jan 2014 17:22:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>adrien</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ponabana.com/?page_id=3546</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<blockquote>
<blockquote><b>UNICEF, in support of the Congolese government, is giving young people in the DRC a platform to defend children’s rights and become active in the decision-making processes that concern them.</b></blockquote>
[accordion]

[section title="CHILDREN'S RIGHTS"]<a href="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/IMG_0240.jpg"><img alt="IMG_0240" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/IMG_0240-1024x682.jpg" width="625" height="416" /></a>

Despite the fact that the promotion of children’s rights has been a central element of the national agenda in recent years, the participation of children has often been merely symbolic. Given these observations, UNICEF and the DRC’s Ministry of Gender, Family Affairs and Children decided to give children a platform and the tools they need to defend their opinions and rights.

[/section]

[section title="<strong>CHILDREN FROM 12 TO 17 YEARS OLD FROM ALL SOCIAL BACKGROUNDS</strong>"]

<img class="alignleft" alt="IMG_0404" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/IMG_0404-300x200.jpg" width="300" height="200" />

Aged from 12 to 17, the "Young Reporters" are girls and boys from all social backgrounds who come from organizations working for the protection, education, health and participation of children in the DRC.

The "Young Reporters" are trained to be more aware of their rights and better prepared to give their views on the problems that they encounter. They are introduced to the Convention on the Rights of the Child (CRC) and practical workshops and games are organized to help them to understand all the issues related to children’s rights.

The children are trained to understand and master basic journalistic techniques. They are taught to master advocacy tools - videos, photos, public games and writing articles. Courses are delivered by a network of journalists and members of the UNICEF DRC team.

[/section]

[section title="<strong>DEFEND YOUR RIGHTS AND EXPRESS YOUR OPINION</strong>"]

The "Young Reporters" program offers participants the opportunity to defend their rights by creating an environment that allows them to express their concerns, ideas, and recommendations to policy makers and managers at all levels. The importance given to their opinion in turn enhances dignity, justice, fairness and equality by placing the interests of children at the heart of the citizenship agenda.
<div><dl id=""><dt><a href="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/291.jpg"><img class="aligncenter" alt="29" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/291.jpg" width="382" height="262" /></a></dt><dd>Les enfants reporters de Goma</dd></dl></div>
[/section]

[section title="<strong>500 YOUTH REPORTERS TRAINED IN DRC's 11 PROVINCES</strong>"]

UNICEF has worked in partnership with the DRC’s Ministry of Gender, Family Affairs and Children so that the program can be implemented in 11 provinces.

Since 2007, nearly 500 children have participated in the program and received basic training in audiovisual production and advocacy techniques to defend the rights of the child.

Some discover a vocation for journalism, humanitarian work or law. The new skills and open-mindedness that this program offers children provide them with greater insight into their country, it's problems and the solutions that can be found.

When asked, most children recognise that now they know their rights, it is their responsibility to respect those of their own children and the children they meet throughout their lives.

The whole point of this program is to enable children to find the solutions to their own problems. They are often excluded from decisions that concern them when it seems obvious that they must be involved in building a more just society that is more respectful of its children.

[/section]

[section title="<strong>A TV SHOW, VIDEOS AND ARTICLES FOR CONCRETE RESULTS</strong>"]

<img class="alignright" alt="IMG_0795" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/IMG_0795-300x200.jpg" width="300" height="200" />

Following a plea by young reporters in Kinshasa, the national television network RTNC has agreed to create a TV show called "The Voice of the Child".

In 2008, the Goma “Young Reporters” produced a series of videos called "Inside Witnesses" on the lives of displaced people in North Kivu. The videos were released internationally by the French newspaper <i>Le Monde</i> and prompted international and national debates.

In 2009, Young Reporters from Matadi found that in special schools for deaf and dumb children, parents had to pay teachers' salaries. Based on the right of children to receive free and quality education, Young Reporters managed with their plea to the Governor to have the teachers’ salaries included in the 2010 budget.

In October 2012, the Francophone Summit was held in Kinshasa. On this occasion, Young Reporters were able to speak with several members of the DRC Parliament whom they alerted about the non-observance of children's rights in their country. They also organised games about advocacy to inform other children about their rights.

One young reporter, Eunice, was invited to the African Union Summit in Addis Ababa where she represented children in Central Africa before African leaders. On this occasion she wrote a remarkable speech called "We, African Children" in which she recalled the right of the child to survival, freedom of expression, education and health, and called for a strategy to prevent armed conflict affecting children.

&nbsp;

<img class="aligncenter" alt="IMG_0420" src="http://ponabana.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/IMG_0420-300x200.jpg" width="300" height="200" />

[/section]

[/accordion]</blockquote>]]></content:encoded>
